article:
Eat Bulaga!
================

Eat Bulaga! is a Philippine television variety show broadcast by TV5 and RPTV. It is the longest-running noontime variety show in the Philippines, airing on television for over 43 years. The show features a mix of entertainment, comedy, public service, and social awareness, making it a staple in Filipino television.

History
--------

### RPN (1979–1989)

Eat Bulaga! premiered on July 30, 1979, on RPN as a noontime variety show created by Television and Production Exponents Inc. (TAPE Inc.). The show's original hosts were Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, Joey de Leon, Chito Pimentel, and Richie D'Horsie. During its early years, the show focused on comedy sketches, musical numbers, and public service segments.

### ABS-CBN (1989–1995)

In 1989, Eat Bulaga! transferred to ABS-CBN, where it continued to air as a noontime variety show. The show's format remained largely the same, with the addition of new hosts and segments. However, the show's popularity began to decline during this period.

### GMA Network (1995–2024)

In 1995, Eat Bulaga! moved to GMA Network, where it experienced a resurgence in popularity. The show's hosts, including Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon, became household names. The show's format was revamped, with the addition of new segments and games. Eat Bulaga! became a ratings success, and it remained as one of the top-rated noontime variety shows in the Philippines.

### TVJ - TAPE Inc. conflict (2023–2024)

In 2023, a conflict arose between the show's hosts, collectively known as TVJ (Tito, Vic, and Joey), and TAPE Inc. over the ownership of the Eat Bulaga! trademark. The conflict led to a split between the two parties, with TVJ launching a new show called E.A.T. and TAPE Inc. continuing to air Eat Bulaga! with a new set of hosts.

#### E.A.T. and TAPE's Eat Bulaga!

E.A.T. (Entertainment, Arts, and Talk) premiered in 2023 as a new noontime variety show hosted by Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon. The show's format was similar to Eat Bulaga!, with a mix of entertainment, comedy, and public service segments. Meanwhile, TAPE Inc. continued to air Eat Bulaga! with a new set of hosts, including new-comers and veteran television personalities.

#### Eat Bulaga! trademark battle: TVJ emerges victorious

In 2024, the Intellectual Property Office of the Philippines ruled in favor of TVJ, granting them ownership of the Eat Bulaga! trademark. The ruling effectively allowed TVJ to use the Eat Bulaga! name, and the show was subsequently renamed Eat Bulaga!.

### TV5 and RPTV (since 2024)

In 2024, Eat Bulaga! transferred to TV5 and RPTV, where it continues to air as a noontime variety show. The show's format remains largely the same, with a mix of entertainment, comedy, and public service segments. The show's hosts, including Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon, continue to entertain and engage with their audience.

Segments
----------

### Current segments

#### Sugod Bahay, Mga Kapatid!

Sugod Bahay, Mga Kapatid! is a daily segment where the show's hosts visit a lucky family and give them prizes and surprises.

#### Gimme 5: Laro ng mga Henyo

Gimme 5: Laro ng mga Henyo is a daily segment where five contestants compete in a series of games and challenges to win prizes.

#### Peraphy

Peraphy is a daily segment where the show's hosts play a word game where they have to come up with words related to a certain theme.

#### Barangay Bulagaan

Barangay Bulagaan is a daily segment where the show's hosts visit a different barangay each day and engage in various activities and games with the residents.

#### Dear Eat Bulaga

Dear Eat Bulaga is a daily segment where the show's hosts answer letters and questions from viewers and offer advice and guidance.

#### Eat Bulaga Olympics

Eat Bulaga Olympics is an annual segment where the show's hosts compete in various sports and games to win prizes and bragging rights.

#### Bawal! Judgmental Ka Ba?

Bawal! Judgmental Ka Ba? is a daily segment where the show's hosts play a game where they have to guess the prices of various items and services.

### Concluded segments

#### Mr. Cutie: Boys Got Talent (2023–2024)

Mr. Cutie: Boys Got Talent was a segment where a group of young men competed in various talent and beauty pageant-style challenges to win prizes and the title of Mr. Cutie.

#### Babala! 'Wag Kayong Ganuuun... (2023–2024)

Babala! 'Wag Kayong Ganuuun... was a segment where the show's hosts played a game where they had to guess the prices of various items and services.

#### That's My Boyfriend (2024)

That's My Boyfriend was a segment where a group of women competed to win the heart of a bachelor and win prizes.

#### Rewind: The Comeback Stage (2024)

Rewind: The Comeback Stage was a segment where past Eat Bulaga! winners and contestants competed to win prizes and a chance to come back on the show.

#### EB Centerstage

EB Centerstage was a segment where the show's hosts performed various musical numbers and dance routines.

#### Barangay Cinema: Child Star of the Year (2024)

Barangay Cinema: Child Star of the Year was a segment where a group of child actors competed to win the title of Child Star of the Year and prizes.

Ratings
--------

Eat Bulaga! has consistently high ratings throughout its run, making it one of the top-rated noontime variety shows in the Philippines.

Controversies
-------------

Eat Bulaga! has been involved in various controversies throughout its run, including a trademark dispute between the show's hosts and TAPE Inc. in 2023.

Spin-offs
----------

### Eat Na Ta!

Eat Na Ta! is a spin-off of Eat Bulaga! that aired on GMA Network from 2020 to 2022. The show was a noontime variety show that featured a mix of entertainment, comedy, and public service segments.

### International versions

#### Eat Bulaga! Indonesia and The New Eat Bulaga! Indonesia

Eat Bulaga! Indonesia and The New Eat Bulaga! Indonesia are Indonesian adaptations of Eat Bulaga! that aired on SCTV and MNCTV from 2012 to 2016.

#### Eat Bulaga! Myanmar

Eat Bulaga! Myanmar is a Burmese adaptation of Eat Bulaga! that aired on MRTV-4 from 2016 to 2018.

Notes
-----

* Eat Bulaga! has won numerous awards throughout its run, including several Best Variety Show awards.
* The show's hosts, including Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon, have become household names in the Philippines.
* Eat Bulaga! has been broadcast in several countries, including Indonesia, Myanmar, and the United States.

----------

* (None)

article:
2022 NBA Finals

The 2022 NBA Finals was the championship series of the National Basketball Association's (NBA) 2021-22 season and conclusion of the playoffs. The series was contested between the Eastern Conference champion Boston Celtics and the Western Conference champion Golden State Warriors. The Warriors won the series 4-2, capturing their fourth NBA championship in eight years.

#Background

##Boston Celtics

The Boston Celtics entered the 2021-22 season with high expectations, having acquired point guard Dennis Schröder and veteran big man Al Horford in the offseason. Led by young stars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, the Celtics got off to a slow start, but eventually found their rhythm and finished the season with a 51-31 record, good for second in the Eastern Conference. In the playoffs, Boston dispatched the Brooklyn Nets in the first round, then defeated the Milwaukee Bucks in seven games in the conference semifinals. In the Eastern Conference Finals, the Celtics faced off against the Miami Heat, winning the series 4-3.

##Golden State Warriors

The Golden State Warriors entered the 2021-22 season after a two-year playoff drought. Led by Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson, and Draymond Green, the Warriors got off to a strong start, but were plagued by injuries throughout the season. Despite this, Golden State finished with a 53-29 record, good for third in the Western Conference. In the playoffs, the Warriors defeated the Denver Nuggets in the first round, then defeated the Memphis Grizzlies in six games in the conference semifinals. In the Western Conference Finals, Golden State faced off against the Dallas Mavericks, winning the series 4-1.

##Road to the Finals

Both teams entered the NBA Finals with a rich history of success. The Celtics were seeking their 18th NBA championship, while the Warriors were seeking their seventh. The two teams had met in the NBA Finals once before, in 1964, when the Celtics defeated the Warriors 4-1.

##Regular season series

The Celtics and Warriors met twice during the regular season, with each team winning on their home court. On December 17, 2021, the Celtics defeated the Warriors 111-107 at TD Garden. On March 16, 2022, the Warriors defeated the Celtics 88-87 at Chase Center.

#Series summary

The NBA Finals began on June 2, 2022, with the Warriors hosting the Celtics at Chase Center. Golden State won the first game 120-108, behind 34 points from Stephen Curry. The Celtics evened the series in Game 2, winning 107-88. The Warriors took a 2-1 lead in the series with a 109-103 win in Game 3. The Celtics tied the series again in Game 4, winning 97-92. The Warriors took a 3-2 lead in the series with a 104-94 win in Game 5. In Game 6, the Warriors closed out the series with a 103-90 win, capturing their fourth NBA championship in eight years.

#Game summaries

##Game 1

Game 1 was played on June 2, 2022, at Chase Center in San Francisco, California. The Warriors won the game 120-108, behind 34 points from Stephen Curry. The Celtics were led by Jayson Tatum, who scored 26 points.

##Game 2

Game 2 was played on June 5, 2022, at Chase Center in San Francisco, California. The Celtics evened the series with a 107-88 win. The Celtics were led by Jayson Tatum, who scored 26 points. The Warriors were led by Stephen Curry, who scored 29 points.

##Game 3

Game 3 was played on June 8, 2022, at TD Garden in Boston, Massachusetts. The Warriors took a 2-1 lead in the series with a 109-103 win. The Warriors were led by Stephen Curry, who scored 31 points. The Celtics were led by Jayson Tatum, who scored 26 points.

##Game 4

Game 4 was played on June 10, 2022, at TD Garden in Boston, Massachusetts. The Celtics tied the series again with a 97-92 win. The Celtics were led by Jayson Tatum, who scored 23 points. The Warriors were led by Stephen Curry, who scored 43 points.

##Game 5

Game 5 was played on June 13, 2022, at Chase Center in San Francisco, California. The Warriors took a 3-2 lead in the series with a 104-94 win. The Warriors were led by Andrew Wiggins, who scored 26 points. The Celtics were led by Jayson Tatum, who scored 27 points.

##Game 6

Game 6 was played on June 16, 2022, at TD Garden in Boston, Massachusetts. The Warriors closed out the series with a 103-90 win, capturing their fourth NBA championship in eight years. The Warriors were led by Stephen Curry, who scored 34 points. The Celtics were led by Jayson Tatum, who scored 24 points.

#Redesigned logo and trophy

For the 2022 NBA Finals, the NBA introduced a redesigned logo and trophy. The new logo features a stylized "NBA" logo with a basketball incorporated into the design. The new trophy features a sleek, modern design with a silver and gold finish.

#Media coverage

The 2022 NBA Finals was broadcast on ABC in the United States, with Mike Breen, Mark Jackson, and Jeff Van Gundy providing commentary. The series was also broadcast on ESPN Radio, with Marc Kestecher, P.J. Carlesimo, and Mark Jackson providing commentary.

##Viewership

The 2022 NBA Finals averaged 12.4 million viewers per game on ABC, making it the most-watched NBA Finals since 2018. Game 6, which saw the Warriors win the championship, averaged 14.2 million viewers, making it the most-watched game of the series.

article:
Anti-Zionism
================

Anti-Zionism is a broad term that encompasses a range of perspectives and movements that oppose Zionism, the nationalist movement that supports the establishment and maintenance of a Jewish state in Palestine, which is now the State of Israel. The term "anti-Zionism" can be applied to individuals, groups, and ideologies that reject the idea of a Jewish homeland, question the legitimacy of the State of Israel, or criticize the actions of the Israeli government. This article will explore the history and development of anti-Zionism, from its early roots to its current forms and manifestations.

Anti-Zionism before 1948
----------------------

### Early Jewish anti-Zionism

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, many Jewish leaders and intellectuals opposed the idea of Zionism. Some argued that a Jewish state would be incompatible with the principles of socialism, while others believed that it would lead to the segregation of Jewish communities from the rest of society. Theodor Herzl, the founder of modern Zionism, faced significant opposition from within the Jewish community, with some critics labeling his ideas as "utopian" or "dangerous."

### Early Arab anti-Zionism

Arab opposition to Zionism began to emerge in the early 20th century, as the Zionist movement gained momentum. Many Arabs saw Zionism as a threat to their own national aspirations and feared that a Jewish state would lead to the displacement of Arab populations. The 1917 Balfour Declaration, which expressed British support for the establishment of a Jewish homeland in Palestine, sparked widespread protests and opposition across the Arab world.

### Reactions to the Balfour Declaration

The Balfour Declaration was met with fierce opposition from Arab leaders and intellectuals, who saw it as a betrayal of Arab interests and a threat to their own national aspirations. The declaration sparked widespread protests and demonstrations across the Arab world, with many calling for the rejection of British rule and the establishment of an independent Arab state.

### Anti-Zionism in the 1920s–1930s

In the 1920s and 1930s, anti-Zionism became a major force in Arab politics, with many leaders and intellectuals advocating for the rejection of Zionism and the establishment of an independent Arab state. The 1920 Nebi Musa riots, which broke out in Jerusalem, marked a turning point in Arab-Jewish relations, with many Arabs seeing Zionism as a direct threat to their own national aspirations.

### The Biltmore programme and its anti-Zionism fall-out

In 1942, the Zionist movement adopted the Biltmore programme, which called for the establishment of a Jewish commonwealth in Palestine. The programme sparked widespread opposition from Arab leaders and intellectuals, who saw it as a direct threat to their own national aspirations. The programme also sparked opposition from within the Jewish community, with some critics arguing that it was too extreme and would lead to conflict with the Arab population.

### Religious

Religious anti-Zionism has been a significant force in both Jewish and Muslim communities. Some Jewish leaders and intellectuals have argued that Zionism is incompatible with Jewish tradition and that the establishment of a Jewish state is a form of idolatry. In the Muslim world, some leaders and intellectuals have argued that Zionism is a form of colonialism and that the establishment of a Jewish state is a threat to Islamic values and principles.

Anti-Zionism after World War II and the creation of Israel
------------------------------------------------------

### 1947–1948

In the aftermath of World War II, the Zionist movement gained significant momentum, with many Jews seeking to establish a homeland in Palestine. The 1947 UN Partition Plan, which called for the division of Palestine into Jewish and Arab states, was met with widespread opposition from Arab leaders and intellectuals, who saw it as a threat to their own national aspirations. The establishment of the State of Israel in 1948 sparked widespread conflict and opposition across the Arab world.

### Soviet Union

In the aftermath of World War II, the Soviet Union emerged as a major opponent of Zionism, viewing it as a form of imperialism and a threat to Arab national aspirations. The Soviet Union provided significant support to Arab states, including Egypt and Syria, in their opposition to Israel.

### Arab and Palestinian anti-Zionism

Arab and Palestinian anti-Zionism has been a significant force in the region, with many leaders and intellectuals advocating for the rejection of Zionism and the establishment of a Palestinian state. The 1967 Six-Day War, which resulted in Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, marked a turning point in Arab-Israeli relations, with many Arabs seeing Zionism as a direct threat to their own national aspirations.

### Perception of Zionism as racism

The perception of Zionism as a form of racism has been a significant theme in anti-Zionist discourse. Many critics argue that Zionism is a form of apartheid, with Israel's treatment of Palestinian Arabs being compared to the treatment of black South Africans under apartheid.

#### During the Cold War

During the Cold War, anti-Zionism became a major force in international politics, with many countries and organizations opposing Israel's existence and viewing Zionism as a form of imperialism.

#### After the Cold War

In the aftermath of the Cold War, anti-Zionism has continued to evolve, with many critics arguing that Zionism is a form of colonialism and that Israel's treatment of Palestinian Arabs is a form of apartheid.

### Islamic perspectives

Islamic perspectives on Zionism have been complex and varied, with some leaders and intellectuals viewing Zionism as a form of colonialism and others seeing it as a threat to Islamic values and principles.

### Left-wing politics

Left-wing politics has been a significant force in anti-Zionist discourse, with many critics arguing that Zionism is a form of imperialism and that Israel's treatment of Palestinian Arabs is a form of apartheid.

### Christian anti-Zionism

Christian anti-Zionism has been a significant force in both Protestant and Catholic communities, with many leaders and intellectuals advocating for the rejection of Zionism and the establishment of a Palestinian state.

#### Protestants

Protestant anti-Zionism has been a significant force, with many leaders and intellectuals advocating for the rejection of Zionism and the establishment of a Palestinian state.

#### Catholics

Catholic anti-Zionism has been a significant force, with many leaders and intellectuals advocating for the rejection of Zionism and the establishment of a Palestinian state.

### Haredi Judaism

Haredi Judaism has been a significant force in anti-Zionist discourse, with many leaders and intellectuals arguing that Zionism is incompatible with Jewish tradition and that the establishment of a Jewish state is a form of idolatry.

Allegations of antisemitism
-------------------------

### Jewish right to a state

The question of whether Jews have a right to a state has been a significant theme in anti-Zionist discourse, with many critics arguing that Zionism is a form of colonialism and that Israel's treatment of Palestinian Arabs is a form of apartheid.

### Equating and correlating anti-Zionism with antisemitism

Some critics have argued that anti-Zionism is a form of antisemitism, with many anti-Zionist activists and organizations being accused of promoting antisemitic views.

### View that the two are not interlinked

Others have argued that anti-Zionism and antisemitism are not interlinked, with many anti-Zionist activists and organizations advocating for the rights of Palestinian Arabs and opposing Israel's treatment of them.

### Shifting positions on the Zionist/Anti-Zionist spectrum

The Zionist/anti-Zionist spectrum has been complex and varied, with many individuals and organizations shifting their positions over time.

### Far-right politics

Far-right politics has been a significant force in anti-Zionist discourse, with many leaders and intellectuals advocating for the rejection of Zionism and the establishment of a white nationalist state.

### Conspiracy theories

Conspiracy theories have been a significant theme in anti-Zionist discourse, with many critics arguing that Zionism is a form of colonialism and that Israel's treatment of Palestinian Arabs is a form of apartheid.

Argentina national football team

The Argentina national football team represents Argentina in men's international football and is controlled by the Argentine Football Association (AFA). The team has a rich history, having won numerous international titles, including two FIFA World Cup trophies, 15 Copa América titles, and two Olympic medals.

# History

The Argentina national football team was founded in 1901 and played its first match against Uruguay in 1902. The team's early years were marked by a rivalry with Uruguay, with whom they contested the first-ever South American Championship in 1910. Argentina's first major international triumph came in 1921, when they won the Copa América, which they would go on to dominate throughout the 20th century.

Argentina's golden generation of the 1970s and 1980s, led by players such as Mario Kempes, Ossie Ardiles, and Diego Maradona, brought the team its first FIFA World Cup title in 1978. They repeated this feat in 1986, with Maradona playing a pivotal role in the team's success. The team has since appeared in four more World Cup finals, finishing as runners-up in 1990, 2006, and 2014.

# Home stadium

The Argentina national team plays its home matches at the Estadio Antonio Vespucio Liberti, also known as the El Monumental, in Buenos Aires. The stadium, which has a seating capacity of over 62,000, is one of the largest and most iconic in South America. The team has also played home matches at other stadiums in Argentina, including the Estadio Ciudad de La Plata and the Estadio Mario Alberto Kempes.

# Team image

The Argentina national team's kit is manufactured by Adidas and features a light blue and white striped jersey, white shorts, and black socks. The team's away kit is typically a dark blue jersey with white shorts and socks. ## Kit suppliers

article:
Marina Ovsyannikova

Marina Ovsyannikova is a Russian journalist and anti-war activist who gained international attention for her bold protest against the Russian invasion of Ukraine on live television. Born in 1978 in Odessa, Ukraine, Ovsyannikova worked for Channel One Russia, one of the country's most prominent state-owned television channels, before her public dissent.

#Early life and career

Marina Ovsyannikova was born in 1978 in Odessa, Ukraine, to a Ukrainian mother and a Russian father. She grew up in a multicultural family and moved to Russia at a young age. Ovsyannikova studied journalism at the Moscow State University and began her career in television as an intern at Channel One Russia. She quickly rose through the ranks, becoming an editor and eventually a producer for the channel's flagship news program, Vremya.

During her tenure at Channel One, Ovsyannikova worked on various high-profile projects, including coverage of the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi and the 2018 FIFA World Cup. She was known for her professionalism and attention to detail, earning the respect of her colleagues and superiors.

#Anti-war protests

On March 14, 2022, Ovsyannikova made headlines around the world when she appeared on live television holding a sign that read "NO WAR" and "Russians against war." The bold protest occurred during a broadcast of Vremya, and Ovsyannikova's message was seen by millions of viewers.

##Pre-recorded message

In addition to her live protest, Ovsyannikova had also pre-recorded a video message in which she spoke out against the war in Ukraine and criticized the Russian government's propaganda efforts. In the video, she stated that she was ashamed of her country's actions and called on Russians to take a stand against the war.

Ovsyannikova's video message was released on social media and quickly went viral, with many praising her courage and conviction. The video was also translated into multiple languages, allowing it to reach a wider audience and further amplify its impact.

##Reactions

Ovsyannikova's protest sparked a range of reactions, both within Russia and internationally. Many Russians praised her bravery and echoed her calls for an end to the war, while others criticized her for being unpatriotic and disloyal to the government.

Internationally, Ovsyannikova was hailed as a hero and a symbol of resistance against the Russian government's authoritarianism. World leaders and human rights organizations praised her courage and condemned the Russian government's actions in Ukraine.

##Persecutions and activism

Following her protest, Ovsyannikova faced persecution and harassment from the Russian authorities. She was detained and questioned by police, and her social media accounts were suspended. Ovsyannikova's family also faced intimidation and threats, with her father reportedly being visited by security agents.

Despite these challenges, Ovsyannikova continued to speak out against the war and advocate for human rights in Russia. She joined forces with other anti-war activists and organizations, using her platform to raise awareness and mobilize support for the cause.

##Criticism

While Ovsyannikova's protest was widely praised, some critics argued that her actions were too little, too late. They pointed out that she had worked for a state-owned television channel for many years, helping to disseminate the government's propaganda and lies.

Others criticized Ovsyannikova for her perceived privilege and elitism, arguing that she had benefited from her position in the media and had only spoken out when it was convenient for her.

#Personal life

Ovsyannikova is married with two children. She has stated that her family has faced significant challenges and risks as a result of her activism, but that she is committed to continuing her work.

In an interview, Ovsyannikova spoke about the emotional toll of her experience, saying that she had faced significant stress and anxiety in the aftermath of her protest. However, she also expressed a sense of pride and purpose, stating that she had found a new sense of meaning in her life through her activism.

2023 Indonesia Open

International recognition of the Donetsk People's Republic and the Luhansk People's Republic

The international recognition of the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and the Luhansk People's Republic (LPR) refers to the diplomatic recognition of these two self-declared states by other countries and entities. The DPR and LPR declared independence from Ukraine in 2014, following a period of unrest in the Donbass region. Since then, the international community has been divided on the question of whether to recognize these entities as independent states.

# History

The Donetsk People's Republic and the Luhansk People's Republic declared independence from Ukraine on April 7 and April 27, 2014, respectively. The declarations of independence were made in response to the Ukrainian government's decision to remove Viktor Yanukovych as President of Ukraine, which was seen as a coup by many in the Donbass region. The DPR and LPR were established with the support of Russia, which has been accused of providing military and economic aid to the separatist movements.

In the years following the declarations of independence, the DPR and LPR have established their own governments, military forces, and economic systems. However, they are not recognized as independent states by the international community, except for Russia, which recognized them as independent states on February 21, 2022.

# Aftermath of Russian recognition

Russia's recognition of the DPR and LPR as independent states has been widely condemned by the international community. The United States, the European Union, and other countries have imposed sanctions on Russia in response to its actions. The Ukrainian government has also condemned Russia's recognition of the DPR and LPR, saying that it is a violation of Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity.

The recognition of the DPR and LPR by Russia has also led to a significant escalation of the conflict in the Donbass region. Fighting between Ukrainian government forces and separatist militants has increased, resulting in the deaths of hundreds of people. The conflict has also had a significant humanitarian impact, with thousands of people displaced and many more affected by the fighting.

# Countries and entities that recognized the DPR and LPR as independent states

## UN member states

* Russia: Recognized the DPR and LPR as independent states on February 21, 2022.

## Non-UN states

* South Ossetia: Recognized the DPR and LPR as independent states on June 18, 2014.
* Abkhazia: Recognized the DPR and LPR as independent states on March 25, 2015.
* Nagorno-Karabakh: Recognized the DPR and LPR as independent states on April 17, 2015.

# Positions by other countries

## Countries and entities that supported recognizing the DPR and LPR as independent states

### UN member states

* Belarus: Has expressed support for the recognition of the DPR and LPR as independent states, but has not officially recognized them.
* Syria: Has expressed support for the recognition of the DPR and LPR as independent states, but has not officially recognized them.
* Venezuela: Has expressed support for the recognition of the DPR and LPR as independent states, but has not officially recognized them.

## Countries and entities that did not support recognizing the DPR and LPR as independent states

### UN member states

* United States: Has condemned Russia's recognition of the DPR and LPR as independent states and has imposed sanctions on Russia in response.
* European Union: Has condemned Russia's recognition of the DPR and LPR as independent states and has imposed sanctions on Russia in response.
* Canada: Has condemned Russia's recognition of the DPR and LPR as independent states and has imposed sanctions on Russia in response.
* Australia: Has condemned Russia's recognition of the DPR and LPR as independent states and has imposed sanctions on Russia in response.

### Non-UN states

* Taiwan: Has condemned Russia's recognition of the DPR and LPR as independent states and has expressed support for Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity.

### International and regional organizations

* United Nations: Has not recognized the DPR and LPR as independent states and has called for a peaceful resolution to the conflict in the Donbass region.
* European Union: Has not recognized the DPR and LPR as independent states and has imposed sanctions on Russia in response to its recognition of the entities.
* Council of Europe: Has not recognized the DPR and LPR as independent states and has called for a peaceful resolution to the conflict in the Donbass region.
* Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe: Has not recognized the DPR and LPR as independent states and has called for a peaceful resolution to the conflict in the Donbass region.

article:
J.K. Rowling

Joanne Kathleen Rowling, better known by her pen name J.K. Rowling, is a British author, screenwriter, and philanthropist best known for writing the Harry Potter fantasy series. The books have gained worldwide recognition and have been translated into over 80 languages, selling more than 500 million copies worldwide, making her one of the best-selling authors of all time.

# Name

J.K. Rowling's full name is Joanne Kathleen Rowling. She was born on July 31, 1965, in Yate, Gloucestershire, England. She adopted the pen name J.K. Rowling for her writing career, using her initials instead of her full name.

# Life and career

## Early life and family

Rowling was born to Peter James Rowling and Anne Volant Rowling. Her father was a Rolls-Royce aircraft engineer, and her mother was a science technician. She has a younger sister, Dianne. The family moved to Winterbourne, Bristol, and later to Tutshill, near Chepstow, Wales. Rowling's parents were both from working-class families, and her early life was marked by financial struggles.

## Secondary school and university

Rowling attended St. Michael's Primary School in Winterbourne, where she wrote her first book, a story about a rabbit called "Rabbit." She then attended Wyedean Comprehensive School and College, where she excelled in languages, particularly French. After completing her secondary education, Rowling moved to London and worked as a researcher and bilingual secretary for Amnesty International.

In 1986, Rowling moved to Manchester and enrolled at the University of Exeter, where she studied French and Classics. During her time at university, she developed a passion for writing and began to write stories in her spare time.

## Inspiration and mother's death

Rowling's mother, Anne, was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in 1990, and Rowling became her primary caregiver. The experience had a profound impact on Rowling's writing, as she drew inspiration from her mother's struggles and incorporated elements of their relationship into her work. Anne Rowling passed away in 1990, and Rowling's grief and sense of loss are reflected in her writing.

## Marriage, divorce and single parenthood

In 1992, Rowling married Portuguese television journalist Jorge Arantes, and the couple had a daughter, Jessica, in 1993. However, the marriage was short-lived, and they divorced in 1995. Rowling then moved to Edinburgh, Scotland, with her daughter and began to focus on her writing career.

## Publishing Harry Potter

Rowling wrote much of the first Harry Potter book in local cafes, as she did not have a computer or a quiet place to work at home. The book was initially rejected by twelve publishers, but Bloomsbury agreed to publish it in 1997. The book, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone," was published in the United Kingdom and became a bestseller.

## Films

The Harry Potter series was adapted into a series of films, with the first film, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone," released in 2001. The films were a critical and commercial success, grossing over $7.7 billion worldwide.

## Religion, wealth and remarriage

Rowling has stated that she was a Christian but had become disillusioned with the Church of England. She has also been open about her struggles with depression and has spoken about the impact of wealth on her life. In 2001, Rowling married anesthetist Dr. Neil Murray, and the couple has two sons, David and Mackenzie.

## Adult fiction and Robert Galbraith

In 2013, Rowling published her first novel for adults, "The Casual Vacancy," which received mixed reviews. She then adopted the pen name Robert Galbraith for her crime fiction series, Cormoran Strike. The series has received critical acclaim, with many praising Rowling's ability to write in a different genre.

## Later Harry Potter works

Rowling has continued to write in the Harry Potter universe, publishing several companion books, including "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them" and "The Tales of Beedle the Bard." She has also written several screenplays, including the film "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them."

## Children's stories

Rowling has also written several children's stories, including "The Ickabog" and "The Christmas Pig." The stories have been praised for their imagination and storytelling.

# Influences

Rowling has cited several authors as influences on her work, including J.R.R. Tolkien, Philip Pullman, and Ursula K. Le Guin. She has also been influenced by mythology and folklore, particularly in her depiction of magical creatures.

# Style and themes

## Style and allusions

Rowling's writing style is characterized by her use of descriptive language and her ability to create vivid characters and settings. She has also been praised for her use of allusions, particularly in her references to mythology and literature.

## Themes

Rowling's work often explores themes of friendship, love, and the struggle between good and evil. She has also written about social issues, such as poverty, prejudice, and the impact of war on civilians.

# Reception

## Gender and social division

Rowling's work has been praised for its portrayal of strong female characters and its exploration of social issues, such as poverty and prejudice. However, some critics have argued that her work reinforces traditional gender roles and social divisions.

## Religious reactions

Rowling's depiction of magic and the wizarding world has been criticized by some religious groups, who have accused her of promoting occultism and Satanism. However, Rowling has stated that her work is not intended to promote any particular religion or worldview.

# Legacy

Rowling's work has had a significant impact on popular culture, inspiring a generation of readers and writers. The Harry Potter series has been translated into over 80 languages and has sold more than 500 million copies worldwide.

# Legal disputes

Rowling has been involved in several legal disputes, including a lawsuit against a fan who published a book of Harry Potter fan fiction. She has also been involved in a dispute with her former assistant, who was accused of stealing money from her.

# Philanthropy

Rowling is a dedicated philanthropist, particularly in the area of multiple sclerosis research. She has also supported several charitable organizations, including the British charity, Comic Relief.

# Views

## Politics

Rowling has been open about her political views, particularly in her criticism of the British Conservative Party. She has also been a vocal supporter of the Labour Party.

## Press

Rowling has been critical of the press, particularly in their treatment of her and her family. She has also been a vocal supporter of press regulation.

## Transgender people

Rowling has been criticized for her views on transgender people, particularly in her comments about the impact of trans women on women's rights. She has also been accused of transphobia.

# Awards and honours

Rowling has received numerous awards and honors for her work, including the National Book Award, the Hugo Award, and the Order of the British Empire.

# Bibliography

article:
Cinema of Russia

The cinema of Russia has a rich and varied history, spanning over a century. From the early days of the Russian Empire to the modern era, Russian cinema has made significant contributions to the world of film. This article provides an overview of the development of Russian cinema, from its early beginnings to the present day.

# Cinema of the Russian Empire

The cinema of the Russian Empire began to take shape in the late 19th century, with the first film screenings taking place in 1896. The early years of Russian cinema were marked by experimentation and innovation, with filmmakers such as Vladimir Romashkov and Vasily Goncharov producing short films that showcased the country's natural beauty and cultural heritage.

One of the most notable filmmakers of the Russian Empire was Yakov Protasanov, who directed the 1913 film "The Queen of Spades," based on the novella by Alexander Pushkin. The film was a critical and commercial success, and helped establish Protasanov as one of the leading figures of Russian cinema.

# Cinema of the Soviet Union

The Russian Revolution of 1917 had a profound impact on the country's film industry. The new Soviet government recognized the potential of cinema as a tool for propaganda and education, and invested heavily in the development of the industry.

## Early Soviet cinema (1917–1953)

The early years of Soviet cinema were marked by a focus on propaganda and ideological correctness. Filmmakers such as Sergei Eisenstein and Dziga Vertov produced films that promoted the ideals of socialism and communism, and helped to shape the country's cultural identity.

One of the most notable films of this period was Eisenstein's "Battleship Potemkin," released in 1925. The film was a masterpiece of montage editing and told the story of the mutiny on the Battleship Potemkin during the Russian Revolution. It was a critical and commercial success, and helped to establish Eisenstein as one of the leading figures of Soviet cinema.

## Late Soviet cinema (1953–1990)

The late Soviet period saw a relaxation of censorship and a growth in creative freedom for filmmakers. Directors such as Andrei Tarkovsky and Nikita Mikhalkov produced films that explored the complexities of Soviet life and culture.

One of the most notable films of this period was Tarkovsky's "Andrei Rublev," released in 1966. The film was a biographical drama about the life of the famous Russian icon painter, and explored themes of art, faith, and creativity. It was a critical and commercial success, and helped to establish Tarkovsky as one of the leading figures of Soviet cinema.

# New Russian cinema

The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 had a profound impact on the Russian film industry. The new Russian government was forced to adapt to a market-based economy, and the industry faced significant challenges in terms of funding and distribution.

## 1990s

The 1990s saw a growth in independent filmmaking in Russia, with directors such as Alexander Sokurov and Pavel Lungin producing films that explored the complexities of post-Soviet life and culture.

One of the most notable films of this period was Sokurov's "The Days of the Eclipse," released in 1988. The film was a drama about a young doctor who becomes embroiled in a mystery in a remote Siberian village. It was a critical and commercial success, and helped to establish Sokurov as one of the leading figures of new Russian cinema.

## 2000s

The 2000s saw a growth in mainstream filmmaking in Russia, with directors such as Timur Bekmambetov and Fyodor Bondarchuk producing films that explored the complexities of post-Soviet life and culture.

One of the most notable films of this period was Bekmambetov's "Night Watch," released in 2004. The film was a supernatural thriller about a group of people who must protect Moscow from a group of vampires. It was a critical and commercial success, and helped to establish Bekmambetov as one of the leading figures of new Russian cinema.

## 2010s

The 2010s saw a growth in international co-productions in Russia, with directors such as Andrey Zvyagintsev and Alexei German producing films that explored the complexities of post-Soviet life and culture.

One of the most notable films of this period was Zvyagintsev's "Leviathan," released in 2014. The film was a drama about a man who must fight against a corrupt government official to save his family's home. It was a critical and commercial success, and helped to establish Zvyagintsev as one of the leading figures of new Russian cinema.

## 2020s

The 2020s have seen a growth in streaming and online content in Russia, with platforms such as Netflix and Amazon Prime producing original content for Russian audiences.

### 2022 boycott

In 2022, a number of Russian filmmakers and actors announced a boycott of the Russian film industry in response to the country's invasion of Ukraine. The boycott was seen as a significant blow to the industry, and highlighted the challenges faced by Russian filmmakers in the current cultural and political climate.

# Russian film production

Russia has a well-developed film industry, with a number of leading production companies and studios. The industry is supported by the government, which provides funding and incentives for film production.

UFC 273: Volkanovski vs. The Korean Zombie

UFC 273: Volkanovski vs. The Korean Zombie was a mixed martial arts event produced by the Ultimate Fighting Championship that took place on April 9, 2022, at the VyStar Veterans Memorial Arena in Jacksonville, Florida, United States.

# Background

The event was originally expected to take place on April 9, 2022, at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, New York, but due to COVID-19 restrictions in New York, the event was moved to the VyStar Veterans Memorial Arena in Jacksonville, Florida. The event was headlined by a featherweight title fight between current champion Alexander Volkanovski and challenger Chan Sung Jung, also known as The Korean Zombie.

The co-main event featured a bantamweight title fight between current champion Aljamain Sterling and challenger Petr Yan. The event also featured a highly anticipated welterweight bout between Gilbert Burns and Khamzat Chimaev.

# Results

## Preliminary Card

The preliminary card featured six bouts, with five of those bouts ending in decision victories. The only finish on the preliminary card came in the opening bout of the event, as Anthony Hernandez submitted Josh Fremd via guillotine choke in the first round.

## Main Card

The main card featured five bouts, with three of those bouts ending in decision victories. The first bout on the main card saw Raquel Pennington defeat Aspen Ladd via split decision. The following bout saw Mickey Gall defeat Mike Malott via unanimous decision.

The third bout on the main card saw Ian Garry defeat Darian Weeks via unanimous decision. The co-main event saw Aljamain Sterling defeat Petr Yan via split decision to retain his bantamweight title.

The main event saw Alexander Volkanovski defeat Chan Sung Jung via TKO in the fourth round to retain his featherweight title.

# Bonus Awards

The following fighters received $50,000 bonuses:

* Fight of the Night: Gilbert Burns vs. Khamzat Chimaev
* Performance of the Night: Alexander Volkanovski
* Performance of the Night: Anthony Hernandez

article:
The Undertaker
================

Mark William Calaway, better known by his ring name The Undertaker, is a retired American professional wrestler and actor. He is best known for his career in WWE, where he worked for over three decades and established himself as one of the most iconic and successful professional wrestlers of all time.

Early Life
-----------

Mark Calaway was born on March 24, 1965, in Houston, Texas. He was raised in a middle-class family with his parents, Frank and Catherine Calaway, and his four siblings. Calaway's early life was marked by a passion for sports, particularly basketball and football, which he played throughout his high school years. After graduating from high school, Calaway attended Texas Wesleyan University, where he studied sports management.

Professional Wrestling Career
-----------------------------

### Early Career (1987-1989)

Calaway began his professional wrestling career in 1987, working for various independent promotions in the southern United States. He adopted the ring name "Texas Red" and competed in several regional promotions, including World Class Championship Wrestling (WCCW) and the United States Wrestling Association (USWA).

### World Championship Wrestling (1989-1990)

In 1989, Calaway signed with World Championship Wrestling (WCW), where he adopted the ring name "Mean Mark Callous." He competed in the WCW's mid-card, feuding with wrestlers such as Sting and Ricky Steamboat.

### World Wrestling Federation/Entertainment/WWE

#### Debut of The Undertaker (1990-1991)

In 1990, Calaway signed with the World Wrestling Federation (WWF), which later became known as the World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE). He adopted the ring name "The Undertaker" and debuted at the 1990 Survivor Series pay-per-view event. The Undertaker's initial character was that of a mysterious and intimidating figure, with a penchant for the dark and macabre.

#### WWF Champion and Beginning of The Streak (1991-1994)

In 1991, The Undertaker defeated Hulk Hogan to win the WWF Championship, marking his first major title reign in the company. During this period, The Undertaker began to establish his undefeated streak at WrestleMania, which would become one of the most iconic and enduring aspects of his career.

#### Rebirthed Deadman (1994-1996)

In 1994, The Undertaker's character underwent a significant transformation, as he adopted a more supernatural and mystical persona. This new character, known as the "Rebirthed Deadman," was marked by a more intense and aggressive in-ring style, as well as a greater emphasis on The Undertaker's supernatural abilities.

#### Lord of Darkness (1996-1998)

In 1996, The Undertaker's character underwent another transformation, as he adopted the persona of the "Lord of Darkness." This character was marked by a greater emphasis on The Undertaker's dark and intimidating presence, as well as a more pronounced use of occult and supernatural themes.

#### Ministry of Darkness Deadman (1998-1999)

In 1998, The Undertaker's character underwent a significant transformation, as he adopted the persona of the "Ministry of Darkness Deadman." This character was marked by a greater emphasis on The Undertaker's role as a messianic figure, as well as a more pronounced use of dark and occult themes.

#### American Badass (2000-2001)

In 2000, The Undertaker underwent a significant transformation, as he adopted the persona of the "American Badass." This character was marked by a greater emphasis on The Undertaker's tough, no-nonsense personality, as well as a more pronounced use of biker and outlaw themes.

#### Big Evil (2001-2003)

In 2001, The Undertaker's character underwent another transformation, as he adopted the persona of "Big Evil." This character was marked by a greater emphasis on The Undertaker's dominant and intimidating presence, as well as a more pronounced use of dark and aggressive themes.

#### Return of the Deadman (2004-2007)

In 2004, The Undertaker's character underwent a significant transformation, as he returned to his roots as the "Deadman." This character was marked by a greater emphasis on The Undertaker's supernatural and mystical abilities, as well as a more pronounced use of dark and occult themes.

#### World Heavyweight Champion (2007-2010)

In 2007, The Undertaker won the World Heavyweight Championship, marking his first major title reign in several years. During this period, The Undertaker established himself as one of the top champions in the WWE, feuding with wrestlers such as Batista and CM Punk.

#### Final Years of The Streak (2011-2014)

In 2011, The Undertaker's undefeated streak at WrestleMania was put on the line against Triple H. The Undertaker emerged victorious, extending his streak to 19-0. The following year, The Undertaker faced CM Punk at WrestleMania, emerging victorious once again. In 2014, The Undertaker faced Brock Lesnar at WrestleMania, ending his undefeated streak at 21-0.

#### Final Feuds (2015-2020)

In 2015, The Undertaker began a feud with Bray Wyatt, which culminated in a match at WrestleMania. The following year, The Undertaker faced Shane McMahon at WrestleMania, emerging victorious. In 2017, The Undertaker faced Roman Reigns at WrestleMania, losing to the younger wrestler. The Undertaker's final match took place at WrestleMania 36, where he faced AJ Styles in a Boneyard match.

#### Retirement and Hall of Fame (2020-2022)

In 2020, The Undertaker announced his retirement from professional wrestling, after a career spanning over three decades. In 2022, The Undertaker was inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame, marking a fitting tribute to his enduring legacy.

#### Sporadic Appearances (2023-Present)

Although The Undertaker has officially retired from professional wrestling, he has made sporadic appearances for the WWE, including a surprise appearance at WrestleMania 39.

Undertaker Gimmick, Identities and Character Evolution
---------------------------------------------------

### The Deadman Identity

The Undertaker's most iconic and enduring character is that of the "Deadman." This character is marked by a supernatural and mystical persona, with a penchant for the dark and macabre.

### Alternate Identities of The Undertaker Gimmick

Prosecution of Donald Trump in New York

The prosecution of Donald Trump in New York refers to the criminal case brought against the 45th President of the United States, Donald Trump, by the New York County District Attorney's Office. The case, which began in 2018, involves allegations of falsifying business records and other crimes related to Trump's dealings with adult film actress Stormy Daniels.

# Background

## Stormy Daniels–Donald Trump scandal

In 2006, Donald Trump had an affair with adult film actress Stormy Daniels. Trump's personal attorney, Michael Cohen, arranged a non-disclosure agreement (NDA) with Daniels, which required her to keep the affair confidential in exchange for a payment of $130,000. The payment was made just before the 2016 presidential election.

## Manhattan DA investigation and grand jury

In 2018, the Manhattan District Attorney's Office launched an investigation into Trump's dealings with Daniels, including the NDA and the payment. The investigation, led by District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr., also examined whether Trump's company, the Trump Organization, had falsified business records related to the payment.

In 2020, a grand jury was convened to investigate the allegations. The grand jury heard testimony from several witnesses, including Cohen, who pleaded guilty to federal charges related to the NDA and the payment.

## Eligibility for president

The prosecution of Trump in New York has raised questions about his eligibility to serve as president. Article II, Section 1 of the United States Constitution requires that the president be a natural-born citizen of the United States, at least 35 years old, and a resident of the United States for at least 14 years. However, the Constitution does not explicitly address the issue of whether a president can be prosecuted while in office.

# Initial proceedings

## Indictment and charges

On March 30, 2023, a grand jury indicted Trump on 34 counts of falsifying business records in the first degree. The indictment alleged that Trump had directed the Trump Organization to falsify records related to the payment to Daniels.

## Arraignment

Trump was arraigned on April 4, 2023, in New York State Supreme Court. He pleaded not guilty to all charges.

# Pre-trial proceedings

## Request for indictment dismissal

In May 2023, Trump's lawyers filed a motion to dismiss the indictment, arguing that the charges were politically motivated and that the prosecution had exceeded its authority.

## Discovery materials and witnesses

In June 2023, the prosecution turned over discovery materials to Trump's lawyers, including documents and witness statements. The prosecution also identified several witnesses who would testify at trial, including Cohen, Daniels, and several employees of the Trump Organization.

## Requests for recusal

In July 2023, Trump's lawyers filed a motion to recuse the trial judge, Juan Merchan, arguing that he had exhibited bias against Trump. The motion was denied.

## Request for removal to federal court

In August 2023, Trump's lawyers filed a motion to remove the case to federal court, arguing that the case involved federal issues and that the federal court had jurisdiction. The motion was denied.

## Trial scheduling

In September 2023, the trial was scheduled to begin on October 2, 2023.

## Gag order

In September 2023, the trial judge issued a gag order, prohibiting Trump and his lawyers from making public statements about the case.

## Statute of limitations

In October 2023, Trump's lawyers argued that the statute of limitations had expired on some of the charges. The prosecution argued that the statute of limitations had been tolled due to Trump's alleged concealment of the crimes.

# Overview of witnesses

The prosecution identified several witnesses who would testify at trial, including:

* Michael Cohen, Trump's former personal attorney
* Stormy Daniels, adult film actress
* David Pecker, CEO of American Media, Inc.
* Hope Hicks, former White House communications director
* Keith Davidson, former attorney for Daniels
* Douglas Daus, former employee of the Trump Organization

# Trial

## Jury selection and opening statements

The trial began on October 2, 2023, with jury selection. The prosecution and defense made opening statements, outlining their cases.

## Contempt hearings

During the trial, Trump's lawyers were held in contempt of court for violating the gag order.

## Prosecution witnesses

### David Pecker

Pecker testified that he had discussed the NDA with Trump and had agreed to pay Daniels $130,000.

### Graff, Farro, Browning, and Thompson

Several employees of the Trump Organization testified that they had been directed to falsify records related to the payment.

### Keith Davidson and Douglas Daus

Davidson and Daus testified that they had been involved in the negotiations for the NDA.

### Hope Hicks

Hicks testified that she had been involved in discussions about the NDA and had advised Trump to pay Daniels.

### McConney, Tarasoff, and Franklin

Several employees of the Trump Organization testified that they had been directed to falsify records related to the payment.

### Stormy Daniels

Daniels testified that she had had an affair with Trump and had been paid $130,000 to keep the affair confidential.

### Manochio, Menzies, and Westerhout

Several employees of the Trump Organization testified that they had been directed to falsify records related to the payment.

### Dixon, Tomalin, Longstreet, and Jarmel-Schneider

Several employees of the Trump Organization testified that they had been directed to falsify records related to the payment.

### Michael Cohen

Cohen testified that he had arranged the NDA and had paid Daniels $130,000.

## Defense witnesses

### Daniel Sitko

Sitko testified that he had been involved in the negotiations for the NDA.

### Robert Costello

Costello testified that he had advised Trump to pay Daniels.

## Closing arguments and jury instructions

The prosecution and defense made closing arguments, and the trial judge instructed the jury on the law.

## Jury deliberations and verdict

The jury deliberated for several days before returning a verdict. Trump was found guilty on 34 counts of falsifying business records in the first degree.

# Post-trial proceedings

## Gag order

The trial judge lifted the gag order, allowing Trump and his lawyers to make public statements about the case.

## Delayed sentencing hearing

The sentencing hearing was delayed until December 2023.

## Immunity ruling

The trial judge ruled that Trump would not be granted immunity from prosecution.

## Firearms and liquor licenses

The New York State Liquor Authority and the New York City Police Department announced that they would review Trump's firearms and liquor licenses.

## Potential appeal of conviction

Trump's lawyers announced that they would appeal the conviction.

# Reactions

The conviction of Trump was widely reported in the media, with many commentators expressing surprise and outrage. Trump's supporters argued that the conviction was politically motivated, while his critics argued that justice had been served.

2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup

The 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup was the 15th edition of the Men's FIH Hockey World Cup, the quadrennial international men's field hockey championship organized by the Fédération Internationale de Hockey (FIH). The tournament was held in Bhubaneswar and Rourkela, India, from January 13 to 29, 2023.

# Host selection

The FIH announced the host country on November 8, 2019. India was awarded the hosting rights for the 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup, beating out bids from Australia, Belgium, and Malaysia. This marked the fourth time India has hosted the Men's Hockey World Cup, following previous editions in 1971, 1982, and 2010.

# Teams

## Qualification

The qualification process for the 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup consisted of several tournaments and events. The top three teams from the 2020–21 FIH Pro League, the winners of the 2022 FIH Hockey World Cup Qualifiers, and the top two teams from the 2022 Pan American Cup qualified directly for the tournament. Additionally, the FIH reserved one spot for the host nation, India.

## Draw

The draw for the 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup was held on September 8, 2022, in Bhubaneswar, India. The 16 participating teams were divided into four pools of four teams each. The pools were determined by the FIH World Rankings, with the top four teams in the world rankings placed in separate pools.

## Squads

Each participating team was required to submit a squad of 18 players, including two goalkeepers, by December 31, 2022.

# Venues

The 2023 Men's FIH Hockey World Cup was held in two venues in India: the Kalinga Stadium in Bhubaneswar and the Birsa Munda International Hockey Stadium in Rourkela.

* Kalinga Stadium (Bhubaneswar): The Kalinga Stadium, also known as the Kalinga Sports Complex, is a multi-purpose stadium located in Bhubaneswar, Odisha. The stadium has a seating capacity of 15,000 and is equipped with state-of-the-art facilities, including a hockey pitch, a swimming pool, and a gymnasium.
* Birsa Munda International Hockey Stadium (Rourkela): The Birsa Munda International Hockey Stadium is a newly constructed stadium located in Rourkela, Odisha. The stadium has a seating capacity of 20,000 and features a world-class hockey pitch, a gymnasium, and other modern facilities.

Azov Brigade

The Azov Brigade, also known as the Azov Regiment, is a far-right volunteer militia group that was formed in Ukraine in 2014. The group was initially composed of ultranationalist and neo-Nazi individuals, but it has since evolved into a more complex organization with multiple branches and ideologies.

# History

## Background and founding, February–April 2014

The Azov Brigade was formed in February 2014, during the Ukrainian Revolution, by a group of ultranationalist activists led by Andriy Biletsky. The group's initial goal was to defend Ukraine against Russian aggression and to promote Ukrainian nationalism. The Azov Brigade was one of several volunteer militias that emerged during this time, but it quickly gained notoriety due to its neo-Nazi ideology and symbols.

## Special Tasks Patrol Police, May 2014

In May 2014, the Azov Brigade was officially recognized by the Ukrainian government as a Special Tasks Patrol Police unit, which gave the group official status and access to government resources. This move was seen as an attempt by the Ukrainian government to co-opt the group and bring it under its control. However, the Azov Brigade continued to maintain its independence and its neo-Nazi ideology.

## Reorganisation and incorporation into the National Guard of Ukraine, November 2014

In November 2014, the Azov Brigade was reorganized and incorporated into the National Guard of Ukraine, a paramilitary force that is responsible for maintaining public order and defending the country against external threats. The group's neo-Nazi ideology was officially renounced, and its leadership was restructured to include more moderate individuals. However, many of the group's original members continued to hold neo-Nazi views, and the group's ideology remained a subject of controversy.

## Battle of Shyrokyne, January 2015

In January 2015, the Azov Brigade played a key role in the Battle of Shyrokyne, a fierce clash between Ukrainian government forces and Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine. The group's performance in the battle was widely praised, and it helped to establish the Azov Brigade as a major player in the Ukrainian military.

## 2016–2019

Between 2016 and 2019, the Azov Brigade continued to play a major role in the conflict in eastern Ukraine. The group was involved in numerous battles against Russian-backed separatists, and it suffered significant casualties. However, the group's ideology and activities continued to be a subject of controversy, both within Ukraine and internationally.

## Russian invasion of Ukraine

In 2022, Russia launched a large-scale invasion of Ukraine, which led to a significant escalation of the conflict. The Azov Brigade played a key role in the defense of Ukraine, particularly in the city of Mariupol, which was besieged by Russian forces.

### Defense of Mariupol

The Azov Brigade was one of the main groups defending Mariupol, which was a key strategic location in eastern Ukraine. The group's fighters were involved in fierce battles against Russian forces, and they suffered significant casualties. However, the group's defense of the city helped to slow down the Russian advance and gave the Ukrainian government time to mobilize its forces.

### Other 'Azov' units

In addition to the Azov Brigade, there are several other units that use the 'Azov' name. These units are often associated with the Azov movement, which is a broader ideological and political movement that promotes Ukrainian nationalism and far-right ideology. Some of these units have been involved in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, while others have been involved in domestic politics and social activism.

# Leadership and organisation

## Commanders

The Azov Brigade has had several commanders since its founding in 2014. Some of the most notable commanders include Andriy Biletsky, who was the group's founder and first commander, and Maxym Shynkarenko, who was the group's commander during the Battle of Shyrokyne.

## Status

The Azov Brigade is currently a part of the National Guard of Ukraine, which is a paramilitary force that is responsible for maintaining public order and defending the country against external threats. The group's status within the National Guard is complex, and it has been the subject of controversy and debate.

## Foreign fighters

The Azov Brigade has attracted foreign fighters from around the world, including from Europe, North America, and Australia. Many of these fighters have been drawn to the group's ideology and its involvement in the conflict in eastern Ukraine. However, the presence of foreign fighters has also been a subject of controversy, particularly in Russia and other countries that have been critical of the Azov Brigade.

# Azov movement

## Azov Civil Corps

The Azov Civil Corps is a social and political organization that is associated with the Azov Brigade. The group was founded in 2015, and it has been involved in a range of activities, including social activism, charity work, and political organizing.

## National Corps

The National Corps is a political party that is associated with the Azov movement. The party was founded in 2016, and it has been involved in Ukrainian politics, including in the 2019 parliamentary elections.

## Youth Corps

The Youth Corps is a youth organization that is associated with the Azov movement. The group was founded in 2015, and it has been involved in a range of activities, including social activism, charity work, and political organizing.

## National Militia, 2017–2020

The National Militia was a paramilitary organization that was associated with the Azov movement. The group was founded in 2017, and it was involved in a range of activities, including maintaining public order and defending the country against external threats. However, the group was disbanded in 2020 due to controversy and criticism.

## Centuria

Centuria is a social and cultural organization that is associated with the Azov movement. The group was founded in 2018, and it has been involved in a range of activities, including promoting Ukrainian culture and identity.

# Human rights violations

The Kerala Story
================

The Kerala Story is a 2023 Indian Hindi-language drama film written and directed by Sudipto Sen. The film is produced by Vipul Amrutlal Shah and starring Adah Sharma, Yogita Bihani, and Sonia Balani. The film's plot is based on the alleged true story of a group of women who were converted to Islam and joined the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS).

Plot
-----

The film tells the story of a group of young women from Kerala, India, who are allegedly lured and converted to Islam by a group of Muslim men. The men, who are portrayed as being part of a larger conspiracy to recruit women for ISIS, use tactics such as love jihad and online grooming to convert the women. The film follows the story of three women, Shalini, Asifa, and Nimah, who are convinced to leave their families and join the ISIS. The film's plot is based on the alleged true story of a group of women who were converted to Islam and joined the ISIS.

Cast

* Yogita Bihani as Asifa

* Sudev Nair as Asifa's love interest
* Kalyanee Mulay as Nimah's love interest
* Siddhi Idnani as a journalist who reports on the story

Production and release
----------------------

The film was produced by Vipul Amrutlal Shah and directed by Sudipto Sen. The film's script was written by Sudipto Sen and the story is based on the alleged true story of a group of women who were converted to Islam and joined the ISIS. The film was shot in various locations in India, including Kerala and Delhi. The film was released in theaters on May 5, 2023.

Premise and factual accuracy
-----------------------------

The film's premise is based on the alleged true story of a group of women who were converted to Islam and joined the ISIS. However, the film's factual accuracy has been questioned by many experts and critics. Many have pointed out that the film's portrayal of the events is exaggerated and sensationalized, and that the film's script is based on unverified reports and hearsay. Additionally, many have questioned the film's depiction of the women as being naive and gullible, and have argued that the film's portrayal of the events is sexist and misogynistic.

Response and Controversy
-------------------------

The film's release was met with controversy and protests from various groups, including Muslim organizations and women's rights groups. Many criticized the film's portrayal of the events and argued that the film was Islamophobic and sexist.

### Promotion by ruling party

The film was promoted by the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and its affiliates. The party's social media handles shared the film's trailer and posters, and many party leaders praised the film for its portrayal of the "truth" about love jihad and ISIS recruitment. However, many critics argued that the party's promotion of the film was part of a larger agenda to polarize the electorate and create a sense of fear and hatred towards Muslims.

### Political opposition

The film was opposed by many opposition parties, including the Indian National Congress and the Communist Party of India (Marxist). Many opposition leaders criticized the film's portrayal of the events and argued that the film was a propaganda tool of the ruling party. Additionally, many opposition leaders pointed out that the film's script was based on unverified reports and hearsay, and that the film's factual accuracy was questionable.

### Public protests

Additionally, many protesters pointed out that the film's script was based on unverified reports and hearsay, and that the film's factual accuracy was questionable.

### Bans and litigation

The film was banned in several states, including Kerala and Tamil Nadu, due to concerns about its portrayal of the events and its potential to create communal tensions. Additionally, several Muslim organizations and individuals filed lawsuits against the film's producers and director, alleging that the film was Islamophobic and defamatory.

Reception

The film received mixed reviews from critics. Many critics praised the film's performances and direction, but criticized its portrayal of the events and its factual accuracy. Additionally, many critics pointed out that the film's script was based on unverified reports and hearsay, and that the film's depiction of the women as being naive and gullible was sexist and misogynistic.

article:
2022 Pacific Typhoon Season

The 2022 Pacific typhoon season is an ongoing event in the annual cycle of tropical cyclone formation, in which tropical cyclones form in the western Pacific Ocean. The season's first named storm, Malakas, formed on January 6, and the season's last named storm, Yamaneko, formed on November 21.

# Seasonal Forecasts

Several national meteorological agencies and scientific institutions forecast how many tropical cyclones will form during a season and/or how many will affect a particular country. These agencies include the Tropical Meteorology Division of the China Meteorological Administration, the Japan Meteorological Agency, the National Meteorological and Hydrological Services of the Philippines, and the National Weather Service's Central Pacific Hurricane Center, among others.

# Seasonal Summary

## Early Season Activity

The season started on January 1, 2022, but no tropical cyclones formed in the western Pacific during the first few weeks of the year. The first tropical depression of the season formed on January 27, but it dissipated without developing further. The first named storm of the season, Malakas, formed on January 6, and it brought strong winds to the Philippines.

## Peak Season Activity

The peak of the season occurred in July and August, with several tropical cyclones forming during these months. In July, the strongest storm of the season, Typhoon Hinnamnor, formed and brought strong winds and heavy rainfall to Japan. In August, several tropical cyclones formed, including Typhoon Muifa, which brought strong winds to China.

## Late Season Activity

The late season activity started in September, with several tropical cyclones forming during this month. In October, several tropical cyclones formed, including Typhoon Nesat, which brought strong winds to Vietnam. In November, the last named storm of the season, Yamaneko, formed and brought strong winds to Japan.

# Systems

## Tropical Depression 01W

Tropical Depression 01W formed on January 27, 2022, and dissipated on January 28, without developing further.

## Typhoon Malakas (Basyang)

Typhoon Malakas formed on January 6, 2022, and dissipated on January 15, after bringing strong winds to the Philippines.

Tropical Storm Trases formed on July 29, 2022, and dissipated on August 1, after bringing heavy rainfall to Japan.

## Tropical Depression 08W

Tropical Depression 08W formed on August 1, 2022, and dissipated on August 2, without developing further.

## Tropical Storm Mulan

Tropical Storm Mulan formed on August 9, 2022, and dissipated on August 11, after bringing heavy rainfall to China.

## Tropical Storm Meari

Tropical Storm Meari formed on August 10, 2022, and dissipated on August 14, after bringing heavy rainfall to Japan.

## Severe Tropical Storm Ma-on (Florita)

Severe Tropical Storm Ma-on formed on August 20, 2022, and dissipated on August 25, after bringing strong winds to China.

## Typhoon Tokage

Typhoon Tokage formed on August 21, 2022, and dissipated on August 24, after bringing strong winds to Japan.

## Typhoon Hinnamnor (Henry)

Typhoon Hinnamnor formed on August 26, 2022, and dissipated on September 6, after bringing strong winds to Japan.

## Tropical Depression 13W (Gardo)

Tropical Depression 13W formed on September 2, 2022, and dissipated on September 3, without developing further.

## Typhoon Muifa (Inday)

Typhoon Muifa formed on September 5, 2022, and dissipated on September 14, after bringing strong winds to China.

## Typhoon Merbok

Typhoon Merbok formed on September 10, 2022, and dissipated on September 15, after bringing strong winds to Japan.

## Typhoon Nanmadol (Josie)

Typhoon Nanmadol formed on September 11, 2022, and dissipated on September 19, after bringing strong winds to Japan.

## Tropical Storm Talas

Tropical Storm Talas formed on September 20, 2022, and dissipated on September 23, after bringing heavy rainfall to Japan.

## Typhoon Noru (Karding)

Typhoon Noru formed on September 22, 2022, and dissipated on September 28, after bringing strong winds to Vietnam.

## Severe Tropical Storm Kulap

Severe Tropical Storm Kulap formed on September 25, 2022, and dissipated on September 29, after bringing heavy rainfall to China.

## Typhoon Roke (Luis)

Typhoon Roke formed on September 30, 2022, and dissipated on October 5, after bringing strong winds to Japan.

## Tropical Depression Maymay

Tropical Depression Maymay formed on October 11, 2022, and dissipated on October 12, without developing further.

## Tropical Depression 21W

Tropical Depression 21W formed on October 13, 2022, and dissipated on October 14, without developing further.

## Tropical Storm Sonca

Tropical Storm Sonca formed on October 15, 2022, and dissipated on October 17, after bringing heavy rainfall to Vietnam.

## Typhoon Nesat (Neneng)

Typhoon Nesat formed on October 15, 2022, and dissipated on October 20, after bringing strong winds to Vietnam.

## Tropical Storm Haitang

Tropical Storm Haitang formed on October 18, 2022, and dissipated on October 20, after bringing heavy rainfall to China.

## Tropical Depression 25W (Obet)

Tropical Depression 25W formed on October 21, 2022, and dissipated on October 22, without developing further.

## Severe Tropical Storm Nalgae (Paeng)

Severe Tropical Storm Nalgae formed on October 26, 2022, and dissipated on November 3, after bringing strong winds to the Philippines.

## Tropical Storm Banyan (Queenie)

Tropical Storm Banyan formed on October 30, 2022, and dissipated on November 1, after bringing heavy rainfall to Vietnam.

## Tropical Storm Yamaneko

Tropical Storm Yamaneko formed on November 21, 2022, and dissipated on November 22, after bringing strong winds to Japan.

## Tropical Storm Pakhar (Rosal)

Tropical Storm Pakhar formed on November 24, 2022, and dissipated on November 25, after bringing heavy rainfall to Vietnam.

## Other Systems

There were several other tropical cyclones that formed during the season, but did not develop further.

# Storm Names

## International Names

The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) uses a list of international names to identify tropical cyclones in the western Pacific. The names are assigned in alphabetical order, and are used in rotation.

### Retirement

The JMA retires the names of tropical cyclones that have caused significant damage or loss of life.

## Philippines

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) uses a separate list of names to identify tropical cyclones that affect the Philippines.

### Retirement

PAGASA retires the names of tropical cyclones that have caused significant damage or loss of life.

# Season Effects

The 2022 Pacific typhoon season had significant effects on several countries in the western Pacific. The season's strongest storm, Typhoon Hinnamnor, caused significant damage and loss of life in Japan. Other storms, such as Typhoon Muifa and Typhoon Nanmadol, also caused significant damage and disruption.

# See Also

* 2022 Atlantic hurricane season

# Notes

This article uses the term "typhoon" to refer to tropical cyclones in the western Pacific, in accordance with the terminology used by the Japan Meteorological Agency.

# References

None.
