article:
Rishi Sunak is a British politician who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 2022 to 2024. He previously held various cabinet positions, including Chancellor of the Exchequer, and was a member of Parliament for the constituency of Richmond (Yorks) since 2015.

#Early life and education (1980–2001)

Rishi Sunak was born on May 12, 1980, in Southampton, England, to Yashvir and Usha Sunak, who are of Indian descent. His father was a general practitioner, and his mother was a pharmacist. Sunak has two younger siblings, Sanjay and Raakhi. He was raised in the suburb of Oakley, Hampshire, and was educated at the local Stroud School.

Sunak attended Winchester College, a private boarding school, where he was head boy and editor of the school newspaper. He then studied philosophy, politics, and economics at Lincoln College, Oxford, graduating with a first-class honors degree in 2001. During his time at Oxford, Sunak was a member of the Oxford Union and the Conservative Association.

#Career

##Business career (2001–2015)

After graduating from Oxford, Sunak worked as an analyst at Goldman Sachs, a multinational investment bank, from 2001 to 2004. He then moved to the hedge fund firm The Children's Investment Fund Management (TCI), where he worked as an analyst from 2006 to 2009. In 2009, Sunak joined the hedge fund firm Theleme Partners, where he worked as a partner until 2013.

##Backbencher (2015–2018)

Sunak was elected as the Conservative Member of Parliament for Richmond (Yorks) in the 2015 general election, succeeding William Hague. As a backbencher, Sunak served on the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Select Committee and was a member of the Conservative Party's Free Enterprise Group.

##Local government under-secretary (2018–2019)

In January 2018, Sunak was appointed as the Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Local Government, a junior ministerial position, by Prime Minister Theresa May. In this role, Sunak was responsible for local government finance, planning, and community cohesion.

##Chief secretary to the Treasury (2019–2020)

In July 2019, Sunak was promoted to Chief Secretary to the Treasury, a senior ministerial position, by Prime Minister Boris Johnson. As Chief Secretary, Sunak was responsible for public spending and taxation.

##Chancellor of the Exchequer (2020–2022)

In February 2020, Sunak was appointed as Chancellor of the Exchequer, succeeding Sajid Javid. As Chancellor, Sunak was responsible for setting the government's budget and economic policy.

###COVID-19 pandemic

During the COVID-19 pandemic, Sunak implemented several measures to support the economy, including the furlough scheme, which provided financial support to businesses and employees affected by the pandemic.

###Furlough scheme

The furlough scheme, also known as the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, was a government program that provided financial support to businesses and employees affected by the pandemic. The scheme allowed businesses to furlough employees, who would receive 80% of their salary from the government, up to a maximum of £2,500 per month.

###Eat Out to Help Out

In August 2020, Sunak launched the Eat Out to Help Out scheme, which provided a 50% discount on food and non-alcoholic drinks at participating restaurants and cafes. The scheme was designed to support the hospitality industry, which had been severely affected by the pandemic.

###Cost of living crisis and energy crisis

In 2021, Sunak faced criticism for his handling of the cost of living crisis and the energy crisis, which saw energy prices rise significantly. Sunak implemented several measures to support households, including a £200 loan to help with energy bills.

###Budgets

As Chancellor, Sunak delivered two budgets, in March 2020 and March 2021. The budgets included measures to support the economy, such as increased public spending and tax cuts.

###Other actions

Sunak also implemented several other measures as Chancellor, including the introduction of a new national insurance contribution for health and social care, and the launch of a new scheme to support businesses affected by the pandemic.

###Resignation

On July 5, 2022, Sunak resigned as Chancellor, along with Health Secretary Sajid Javid, citing a loss of confidence in Prime Minister Boris Johnson's leadership.

##Conservative leadership bids

Sunak ran for the Conservative leadership twice, in 2022 and 2023. In the 2022 leadership election, Sunak lost to Liz Truss, but in the 2023 election, he won, becoming the leader of the Conservative Party.

#Premiership (2022–2024)

Sunak became Prime Minister on October 25, 2022, following the resignation of Liz Truss. He formed a new government, with a cabinet that included several new ministers.

##Cabinet

Sunak's cabinet included several new ministers, including Jeremy Hunt as Chancellor, and Suella Braverman as Home Secretary.

###Reshuffles

Sunak conducted two cabinet reshuffles, in February 2023 and September 2023. The reshuffles saw several ministers moved to new roles, and several new ministers appointed.

##Foreign policy

Sunak's government pursued several foreign policy initiatives, including increased support for Ukraine in its conflict with Russia, and a new agreement with the European Union on trade and security.

###Immigration

Sunak's government introduced several new policies on immigration, including a new points-based system for skilled workers, and increased funding for border control.

###Russia and Ukraine

Sunak's government provided significant support to Ukraine in its conflict with Russia, including military aid and economic sanctions against Russia.

###Israel and Palestine

Sunak's government maintained a neutral stance on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but provided humanitarian aid to Gaza and supported a two-state solution.

##Local election results

In the 2023 local elections, the Conservative Party lost several hundred seats, but Sunak's government maintained a majority in the House of Commons.

##2024 general election and resignation

In the 2024 general election, the Conservative Party lost power to the Labour Party, and Sunak resigned as Prime Minister on May 10, 2024.

#Post-premiership (2024–present)

Sunak became Leader of the Opposition on May 10, 2024, following his resignation as Prime Minister.

##Leader of the Opposition (2024–present)

As Leader of the Opposition, Sunak has been critical of the new Labour government, particularly on issues such as the economy and national security.

#Political positions

Sunak has been described as a moderate Conservative, who supports a mix of free market economics and social liberalism. He has been critical of populism and nationalism, and has advocated for greater international cooperation.

#Public image

Sunak has been seen as a capable and competent politician, who is well-respected by his colleagues and opponents. However, he has also faced criticism for his handling of several issues, including the cost of living crisis and the energy crisis.

#Personal life

Sunak is married to Akshata Murty, an Indian businesswoman and daughter of Narayana Murty, the founder of Infosys. The couple has two daughters, Anoushka and Krishna. Sunak is a practicing Hindu and has been open about his faith.

article:
James Webb Space Telescope
==========================

The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is a space telescope that was launched on December 25, 2021, and is considered one of the most complex and ambitious space telescopes ever built. The JWST is designed to conduct infrared astronomy, observing the universe in the infrared spectrum, and is the successor to the Hubble Space Telescope. The telescope is named after James E. Webb, the second administrator of NASA.

Features
--------

### Location and orbit

The JWST is located in a halo orbit around the L2 (Lagrange point 2), a gravitationally stable location approximately 1.5 million kilometers (930,000 miles) from Earth. This location allows the telescope to maintain a constant distance from the Earth and Sun, keeping its instruments at a stable temperature.

### Sunshield protection

The JWST has a large sunshield that protects its instruments from the heat and light of the Sun. The sunshield is made of five layers of a material called Kapton, which is designed to reflect sunlight and keep the instruments cool. The sunshield is 22 meters (72 feet) in diameter and is shaped like a kite.

### Optics

The JWST has a 6.5-meter (21-foot) primary mirror made of 18 hexagonal mirrors that are made of beryllium. The mirrors are designed to be extremely lightweight and are coated with a thin layer of gold to reflect infrared radiation. The telescope also has a secondary mirror that is used to focus the light from the primary mirror.

### Scientific instruments

The JWST has four scientific instruments:

* The Near-Infrared Camera (NIRCam) is designed to observe the universe in the near-infrared spectrum.
* The Near-Infrared Spectrograph (NIRSpec) is designed to analyze the light from distant objects.
* The Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) is designed to observe the universe in the mid-infrared spectrum.
* The Fine Guidance Sensor (FGS) is used to guide the telescope and maintain its position.

### Spacecraft bus

The JWST has a spacecraft bus that provides power, communication, and navigation for the telescope. The spacecraft bus is equipped with solar panels, batteries, and a communication antenna.

### Servicing

The JWST is designed to be serviced by astronauts, but it is not planned to be serviced in the near future. The telescope has a number of features that make it difficult to service, including its location at L2 and its complex instrument suite.

### Software

The JWST has a sophisticated software system that controls the telescope and its instruments. The software is designed to be highly reliable and fault-tolerant, and is capable of operating the telescope in a variety of modes.

Comparison with other telescopes
-------------------------------

The JWST is one of the most advanced space telescopes ever built, and is designed to conduct a wide range of scientific observations. It is more powerful than the Hubble Space Telescope, and has a number of features that make it unique, including its sunshield and its ability to observe the universe in the infrared spectrum.

Development history
-------------------

### Background (development to 2003)

The Oyo Empire is a rival kingdom that has been at war with Dahomey for years, and Nanisca is determined to protect her kingdom and its people.

As Nanisca trains her warriors, she also must confront her own past and the traumas that she has experienced. She is haunted by the memory of her sister, who was taken by the Oyo Empire as a child, and she is determined to find her and bring her home.

article:
Music written in all major or minor keys

Music written in all major or minor keys refers to a collection of musical pieces that cover all 24 major and minor keys. This concept has been explored by various composers throughout history, resulting in some of the most iconic and enduring works in the classical music repertoire. This article will delve into notable sets that cover all 24 keys, variants, keys, order of keys, history, and notable composers who have contributed to this tradition.

# Notable sets that cover all 24 keys

Several composers have written sets of pieces that cover all 24 major and minor keys. These sets often showcase a composer's mastery of harmony, counterpoint, and composition.

## Composers who wrote multiple sets

Some notable composers who wrote multiple sets of pieces covering all 24 keys include:

* Johann Sebastian Bach: Bach wrote two sets of preludes and fugues, known as "The Well-Tempered Clavier," which cover all 24 major and minor keys.
* Frédéric Chopin: Chopin wrote two sets of etudes, Opp. 10 and 25, which cover all 24 major and minor keys.
* Franz Liszt: Liszt wrote a set of etudes, "Etudes d'execution transcendante," which cover all 24 major and minor keys.
* Sergei Rachmaninoff: Rachmaninoff wrote two sets of etudes, Opp. 33 and 39, which cover all 24 major and minor keys.

# Variants

While sets of pieces covering all 24 keys are the most common, there are other variants that explore similar concepts.

## Single pieces that modulate through many keys

Some pieces, such as Chopin's "Fantaisie-Impromptu" and Liszt's "La campanella," modulate through multiple keys, often covering a significant portion of the 24 keys.

## Works covering all eight church modes

The eight church modes, also known as the Gregorian modes, were used in early Christian music. Some composers, such as Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina, wrote works that cover all eight church modes.

## Other sets of 24 pieces

Some composers have written sets of 24 pieces that do not necessarily cover all 24 major and minor keys. For example, Antonín Dvořák's "Slavonic Dances" and Johannes Brahms's "Hungarian Dances" are sets of 24 pieces that explore folk music traditions.

# Keys

The order in which keys are presented in published works can vary.

## Order of keys in published works

Some common orders include:

* The "circle of fifths," which arranges keys in a circle based on their tonal relationships.
* The "chromatic order," which arranges keys in a linear sequence based on their pitch.
* The "tonal order," which arranges keys based on their tonal relationships.

# History

The concept of writing music in all major or minor keys has a rich history.

## Bach and his precursors

Johann Sebastian Bach's "The Well-Tempered Clavier" is one of the most famous sets of pieces covering all 24 keys. However, Bach was not the first composer to explore this concept. Earlier composers, such as Giovanni Maria Bononcini and Alessandro Scarlatti, wrote sets of pieces that covered multiple keys.

## After Bach

After Bach, many composers wrote sets of pieces covering all 24 keys. Some notable examples include:

### 18th and 19th centuries

#### 1750–1850

* Christian Gottlob Neefe: Neefe wrote a set of preludes and fugues that cover all 24 major and minor keys.
* Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart: Mozart wrote a set of preludes and fugues that cover all 24 major and minor keys.

#### 1851–1900

* Frédéric Chopin: Chopin wrote two sets of etudes, Opp. 10 and 25, which cover all 24 major and minor keys.
* Franz Liszt: Liszt wrote a set of etudes, "Etudes d'execution transcendante," which cover all 24 major and minor keys.

### 20th century

#### 1901–1950

* Sergei Rachmaninoff: Rachmaninoff wrote two sets of etudes, Opp. 33 and 39, which cover all 24 major and minor keys.
* Béla Bartók: Bartók wrote a set of piano pieces, "Mikrokosmos," which cover all 24 major and minor keys.

#### 1951–2000

* Olivier Messiaen: Messiaen wrote a set of piano pieces, "Vingt regards sur l'enfant-Jésus," which cover all 24 major and minor keys.
* György Ligeti: Ligeti wrote a set of piano pieces, "Musica ricercata," which cover all 24 major and minor keys.

### 21st century

* Thomas Adès: Adès wrote a set of piano pieces, "The Tempest," which cover all 24 major and minor keys.
* Daníel Bjarnason: Bjarnason wrote a set of piano pieces, "Over Light Earth," which cover all 24 major and minor keys.

# Notes

This article has provided an overview of music written in all major or minor keys. From Bach's "The Well-Tempered Clavier" to modern sets of pieces, this concept has been explored by many composers throughout history.

Viktor An
================

Viktor An is a Russian short track speed skater of Korean descent. Born on November 23, 1985, in Seoul, South Korea, An has had a storied career, marked by numerous accolades and controversies. As one of the most successful short track speed skaters in history, An has won multiple Olympic and World Championship titles, as well as a record number of World Cup medals.

Early Life and Education
-------------------------

An was born in Seoul, South Korea, where he began skating at a young age. He was trained by the Korea Skating Union (KNSU) and quickly rose through the ranks, becoming a promising young skater. An's early life was marked by intense training and dedication to his craft, which would eventually pay off in his successful career.

Career
--------

### 2000s

#### Early Career and the 2002 Winter Olympics

An's international career began in the early 2000s, when he was just a teenager. He quickly made a name for himself, winning multiple World Junior Championship titles. In 2002, An represented South Korea at the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, where he won his first Olympic gold medal in the 1000m event.

#### National Team 'Recommendation System'

During this period, An was also part of the KNSU's "recommendation system," which allowed top skaters to receive preferential treatment and support. This system has been criticized for creating a culture of favoritism and corruption within the KNSU.

#### 2002–2005, KNSU and Non-KNSU

Between 2002 and 2005, An continued to compete for South Korea, winning multiple World Championship titles and World Cup medals. However, he also began to experience conflicts with the KNSU, which would eventually lead to his departure from the organization.

#### 2005, Conflict with Korea Skating Union

In 2005, An had a public falling out with the KNSU, which he accused of corruption and favoritism. The conflict ultimately led to An's departure from the KNSU and his decision to compete as an independent athlete.

#### 2006 Winter Olympics

At the 2006 Winter Olympics in Torino, An competed as an independent athlete, winning multiple gold medals and cementing his status as one of the world's top short track speed skaters.

#### After Torino

After the 2006 Winter Olympics, An continued to compete at the highest level, winning multiple World Championship titles and World Cup medals. However, he also began to experience conflicts with the KNSU, which he accused of trying to sabotage his career.

#### Injury in Early 2008

In early 2008, An suffered a serious injury that kept him out of competition for several months. The injury forced An to reevaluate his career and consider retirement.

### 2010s

#### 2010, Conflict with Korea Skating Union

In 2010, An had another public falling out with the KNSU, which he accused of corruption and favoritism. The conflict ultimately led to An's decision to naturalize to Russia and compete for the Russian national team.

#### Naturalization to Russia

In 2011, An naturalized to Russia and began competing for the Russian national team. The decision was met with controversy, with some accusing An of betraying his native South Korea.

#### 2011, Conflict with the South Korean Coaches

In 2011, An had a public falling out with the South Korean coaches, who he accused of trying to sabotage his career. The conflict ultimately led to An's decision to sever ties with the South Korean skating community.

#### Heading to Sochi

At the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, An competed for Russia, winning multiple gold medals and cementing his status as one of the world's top short track speed skaters.

#### 2014 Winter Olympics

At the 2014 Winter Olympics, An won multiple gold medals, including the 1000m and 500m events. The victories cemented An's status as one of the greatest short track speed skaters in history.

#### After Sochi

After the 2014 Winter Olympics, An continued to compete at the highest level, winning multiple World Championship titles and World Cup medals. However, he also began to experience conflicts with the Russian skating community, which he accused of favoritism and corruption.

#### Retirement

In 2018, An announced his retirement from competitive skating, citing a desire to pursue other interests and spend more time with his family.

### 2020s

#### 2022 Winter Olympics

At the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing, An competed as a member of the Russian Olympic Committee (ROC) team, winning multiple gold medals and cementing his status as one of the greatest short track speed skaters in history.

#### Failure to Return to South Korea for Coaching

In 2022, An was offered a coaching position with the South Korean national team, but he declined, citing a desire to remain in Russia and pursue other interests.

#### South Korean Leadership Activities

In 2022, An became involved in South Korean leadership activities, including work with the Korea Sports Promotion Foundation. The move was seen as a way for An to give back to his native country and promote the development of short track speed skating.

Conflict with Mentor
--------------------

Throughout his career, An has had a complex and often contentious relationship with his mentor, Ahn Hyun-soo. The two have had public falling outs and have disagreed on a range of issues, including training methods and team selection.

Style
------

An is known for his aggressive and physical skating style, which has earned him both praise and criticism. He is also known for his ability to perform under pressure and his clutch gene, which has allowed him to win multiple gold medals in high-pressure situations.

Awards and Honors
-----------------

An has won numerous awards and honors throughout his career, including multiple Olympic and World Championship titles. He has also been recognized for his contributions to short track speed skating, including his work with the Korea Sports Promotion Foundation.

Personal Life
-------------

### Russian Citizenship

In 2011, An naturalized to Russia and became a Russian citizen. The decision was met with controversy, with some accusing An of betraying his native South Korea.

### Political Issues

An has been involved in several high-profile controversies throughout his career, including conflicts with the KNSU and the Russian skating community. He has also been accused of being involved in corrupt practices, including match-fixing and doping.

Notes
-----

In the Media
-------------

An has been featured in numerous media outlets throughout his career, including television, print, and online publications. He has also been the subject of several documentaries and profiles, including a 2020 documentary on his life and career.

Chess World Cup 2023

The Chess World Cup 2023 is a 128-player single-elimination chess tournament scheduled to take place from July 29 to August 24, 2023, in Baku, Azerbaijan. The tournament is part of the World Chess Championship cycle and will determine two players who will qualify for the 2024 World Chess Championship Candidates Tournament.

# Format

The Chess World Cup 2023 is a knockout tournament, where players compete in a series of matches, with the winner advancing to the next round and the loser being eliminated. Each match consists of two classical games, with the player scoring 1.5 or more points advancing to the next round. If the score is tied 1-1, the players will play a tiebreaker, consisting of two rapid games, followed by two blitz games, and finally, an armageddon game if necessary.

## Schedule

The tournament is scheduled to take place from July 29 to August 24, 2023, with the following rounds:

* Round 1: July 29-30
* Round 2: July 31-August 1
* Round 3: August 2-3
* Round 4: August 4-5
* Round 5: August 6-7
* Round 6: August 8-9
* Round 7: August 10-11
* Round 8: August 12-13

## Prize money

The total prize fund for the tournament is $1.5 million, with the winner receiving $110,000 and the runner-up receiving $55,000.

# Participants

The tournament features 128 players, including the top-ranked players in the world, as well as players who qualified through various tournaments and events.

## Qualifier explanation

Players qualified for the tournament through the following methods:

* The top 30 players in the FIDE world rankings as of June 2023
* The top 20 players from the FIDE World Cup 2021

* The top 10 players from the FIDE World Cup 2023 qualifiers
* The top 5 players from the FIDE Grand Swiss 2022
* The top 3 players from the FIDE World Youth Championship 2022

* 5 players nominated by the FIDE

article:
Lafayette Ronald Hubbard, known to his followers as L. Ron Hubbard, was an American author, philosopher, and the founder of Scientology. Born on March 13, 1911, in Tilden, Nebraska, Hubbard's life was marked by a series of transformations, from a young science fiction writer to a self-help author, and eventually to the founder of a global religious movement.

# Life

## Before Dianetics

### Pre-war fiction

Hubbard's early life was marked by a passion for writing. He began writing science fiction stories in his teenage years and published his first stories in 1934. Throughout the 1930s, Hubbard wrote prolifically, producing numerous short stories, novels, and screenplays. His writing career was interrupted by World War II, during which he served in the US Navy.

### Military career

In 1941, Hubbard joined the US Navy, where he served on various ships and eventually became the commanding officer of a patrol boat. Hubbard's military career was marked by controversy, with some questioning the accuracy of his war stories and the extent of his injuries. Despite this, Hubbard was awarded several medals for his service.

### After the war

After the war, Hubbard returned to writing, producing works such as "Fear" (1940) and "Typewriter in the Sky" (1940). He also became involved in the Los Angeles science fiction community, befriending authors such as Robert A. Heinlein and Arthur C. Clarke.

## In the Dianetics era

In 1949, Hubbard began developing his self-help system, Dianetics. He drew on his experiences as a science fiction writer, as well as his interests in psychology and philosophy, to create a system that aimed to help people overcome their mental and emotional traumas. Hubbard's book "Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health" (1950) became a bestseller, and Dianetics quickly gained a following.

## Pivot to Scientology

As Hubbard continued to develop Dianetics, he began to incorporate spiritual and philosophical elements into his teachings. In 1952, he founded the first Scientology church in Wichita, Kansas. Hubbard's new movement, Scientology, aimed to help individuals achieve spiritual enlightenment and freedom from the constraints of the material world.

## In the Church of Scientology era

Throughout the 1950s and 1960s, Hubbard expanded Scientology, establishing churches and training centers around the world. He also developed a range of spiritual practices, including auditing, which aimed to help individuals overcome their past traumas and achieve spiritual enlightenment.

## In the Sea Org era

In 1967, Hubbard founded the Sea Organization (Sea Org), a paramilitary organization within Scientology. The Sea Org aimed to provide a more disciplined and dedicated group of followers, who would help Hubbard to expand Scientology and protect it from external threats.

## In hiding

In the 1970s, Hubbard's personal life became increasingly reclusive. He lived on a ship, the Apollo, which sailed around the world, and eventually settled in a secret location in California. Hubbard's health declined in the 1980s, and he died on January 24, 1986, at the age of 74.

# Sources and doctrines

Hubbard's teachings drew on a range of sources, including science fiction, philosophy, psychology, and spirituality. His doctrines, as outlined in his numerous books and lectures, emphasized the importance of self-improvement, spiritual growth, and the attainment of spiritual freedom.

# False biographical claims

Throughout his life, Hubbard made several false claims about his biography, including his military service and his academic achievements. These claims have been extensively debunked by critics and scholars.

# Legacy

## In Scientology

Hubbard's legacy within Scientology is deeply contested. To his followers, he is revered as a spiritual leader and a visionary. However, critics have questioned the accuracy of his teachings and the authoritarian nature of the Scientology organization.

## In popular culture

article:
2022 Johor state election

The 2022 Johor state election was held on 12 March 2022 to elect the 56 members of the 15th Johor State Legislative Assembly, the unicameral legislature of the Malaysian state of Johor. The election was called following the dissolution of the 14th Johor State Legislative Assembly on 22 January 2022. This was the 15th Johor state election since the independence of Malaya (now Malaysia) in 1957.

# Election cycles

The Johor state election is held concurrently with the general election for the Malaysian Parliament, with the exception of the 1974 Johor state election, which was held separately. The election is usually held every five years, unless the state assembly is dissolved earlier. The 2022 Johor state election was held earlier than scheduled due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the subsequent state of emergency.

# Electoral system

The Johor state election uses the first-past-the-post (FPTP) system, where the candidate with the most votes in each constituency is declared the winner. The election is held in 56 single-member constituencies, with each constituency electing one member to the Johor State Legislative Assembly.

# Constituencies

The 56 constituencies in Johor were determined by the Election Commission of Malaysia, an independent body responsible for conducting elections in Malaysia. The constituencies were redrawn in 2018 to reflect changes in population and voter demographics.

# Composition before dissolution

Before the dissolution of the 14th Johor State Legislative Assembly, the composition of the assembly was as follows:

* Barisan Nasional (BN): 37 seats
* Pakatan Harapan (PH): 15 seats
* Perikatan Nasional (PN): 2 seats
* Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (BERSATU): 2 seats

# Timeline

## Events from the Dissolution of the Johor State Legislative Assembly to the Issue of the Writ of Election (22 January to 9 February 2022)

* 22 January 2022: The 14th Johor State Legislative Assembly was dissolved, marking the beginning of the 2022 Johor state election campaign period.
* 24 January 2022: The Election Commission of Malaysia announced that the nomination day would be held on 26 February 2022.
* 31 January 2022: The Johor Sultan, Ibrahim Iskandar, granted the dissolution of the state assembly.

## Events from the Issue of the Writ of Election to the Nomination Day (10 to 26 February 2022)

* 10 February 2022: The Election Commission of Malaysia issued the writ of election, marking the official start of the election campaign period.
* 15 February 2022: The Pakatan Harapan (PH) coalition announced its candidates for the election.
* 20 February 2022: The Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition announced its candidates for the election.
* 22 February 2022: The Perikatan Nasional (PN) coalition announced its candidates for the election.
* 26 February 2022: Nomination day was held, with candidates from various parties submitting their nomination papers.

## Events from the Nomination Day to the Early Polling Day for Postal and Advance Voters & Campaigning Period (27 February to 12 March 2022)

* 28 February 2022: The campaigning period began, with candidates and parties campaigning for votes.
* 5 March 2022: Early polling day was held for postal and advance voters.
* 8 March 2022: The campaigning period ended.
* 12 March 2022: Polling day was held, with voters casting their ballots.

# Electoral candidates

A total of 233 candidates from various parties contested in the election. The main coalitions and parties that contested in the election were:

* Barisan Nasional (BN)
* Pakatan Harapan (PH)
* Perikatan Nasional (PN)
* Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (BERSATU)
* Malaysian United Democratic Alliance (MUDA)
* Parti Rakyat Malaysia (PRM)

# Results

The results of the 2022 Johor state election were as follows:

## By parliamentary constituency

* Johor Bahru: Pakatan Harapan (PH) won 5 seats, Barisan Nasional (BN) won 2 seats
* Johor Bahru: Perikatan Nasional (PN) won 1 seat
* Gelang Patah: Pakatan Harapan (PH) won 4 seats, Barisan Nasional (BN) won 2 seats
* Kulai: Pakatan Harapan (PH) won 4 seats, Barisan Nasional (BN) won 2 seats
* Pasir Gudang: Pakatan Harapan (PH) won 3 seats, Barisan Nasional (BN) won 2 seats
* Tebrau: Pakatan Harapan (PH) won 4 seats, Barisan Nasional (BN) won 1 seat

## Seats that changed allegiance

* 24 seats changed allegiance, with Pakatan Harapan (PH) winning 12 seats from Barisan Nasional (BN) and Perikatan Nasional (PN) winning 5 seats from Barisan Nasional (BN).

# Election pendulum

The election pendulum shows the seats that changed allegiance and the seats that were retained by the winning parties.

# Departing incumbents

Several incumbents lost their seats in the election, including:

* Osman Sapian (Pakatan Harapan)
* Md Yunos Husin (Barisan Nasional)
* Abd Mutalip Abd Rahim (Barisan Nasional)

# Controversies and issues

The election was marred by several controversies and issues, including:

* Allegations of vote-buying and corruption
* Disputes over the use of government resources for campaigning
* Concerns over the distribution of postal votes

# Aftermath

The 2022 Johor state election saw a significant shift in the political landscape of Johor, with Pakatan Harapan (PH) winning the most seats. The election also saw the rise of Perikatan Nasional (PN) as a major player in Johor politics.

article:
2023 Israeli Judicial Reform

The 2023 Israeli judicial reform refers to a series of proposed changes to the Israeli judicial system, which were introduced by the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in January 2023. The reforms aim to significantly alter the powers and structure of the Israeli judiciary, sparking intense debate and controversy within Israeli society and internationally.

# Background

## Israeli Supreme Court and judicial review

The Israeli Supreme Court, also known as the High Court of Justice (HCJ), is the highest court in the Israeli judicial system. Established in 1948, the Court has played a crucial role in shaping the country's constitutional law and ensuring the protection of individual rights. One of the Court's key powers is its ability to conduct judicial review, which enables it to review and strike down laws and government decisions that it deems unconstitutional or unreasonable.

## 1992 Constitutional Revolution and its discontents

In 1992, the Israeli Supreme Court underwent a significant transformation, known as the Constitutional Revolution. During this period, the Court adopted a more activist approach to judicial review, striking down several laws and government decisions that it deemed inconsistent with Israel's Basic Laws. While the Constitutional Revolution was hailed by some as a significant step forward for Israeli democracy, others criticized the Court for overstepping its authority and undermining the power of the elected branches of government.

## 2018–2022 Israeli political crisis and 2022 legislative election

Between 2018 and 2022, Israel experienced a prolonged period of political instability, marked by four inconclusive elections and a succession of caretaker governments. In the 2022 legislative election, the right-wing Likud party, led by Benjamin Netanyahu, emerged as the largest party, but failed to secure a majority. Netanyahu ultimately formed a coalition government with several right-wing and ultra-Orthodox parties, which included several ministers who had long been critical of the Israeli judiciary.

# Legislative history

## HCJ 5658/23 Movement for Quality Government in Israel v. Knesset (2024)

In response to the proposed reforms, several petitioners, including the Movement for Quality Government in Israel, filed a petition with the High Court of Justice, challenging the constitutionality of the reforms. The case, known as HCJ 5658/23, is ongoing, and a decision is expected in 2024.

# Proposed changes

## Judicial selection

### Current system

Under the current system, judges are selected by the Judicial Selection Committee, a nine-member panel consisting of three Supreme Court justices, two cabinet ministers, two Knesset members, and two representatives of the Israel Bar Association. The Committee operates by consensus, and its recommendations are typically adopted by the government.

### Proposed system

The proposed reforms would significantly alter the composition of the Judicial Selection Committee, increasing the number of politicians on the panel and reducing the number of judges. Under the new system, the Committee would consist of 11 members, including four politicians, three judges, and four representatives of the Israel Bar Association.

### Arguments in favor of the reform

Proponents of the reform argue that the current system is too opaque and allows the judiciary to select its own members, leading to a lack of diversity and a narrow range of perspectives. By increasing the number of politicians on the Committee, the reform aims to introduce more diverse perspectives and ensure that judges are more accountable to the elected branches of government.

### Arguments against the reform

Critics of the reform argue that it would undermine the independence of the judiciary and allow politicians to pack the courts with sympathetic judges. By reducing the number of judges on the Committee, the reform would also reduce the ability of the judiciary to ensure that new judges have the necessary qualifications and experience.

## Government legal advisors

The proposed reforms would also give the government greater control over the appointment of government legal advisors, including the Attorney-General. Under the current system, the Attorney-General is appointed by the government, but is also responsible for advising the government on the legality of its actions. The reform would allow the government to appoint a new Attorney-General who is more sympathetic to its views.

## Constitutional review

The proposed reforms would limit the ability of the High Court of Justice to conduct constitutional review, restricting its ability to strike down laws and government decisions that are deemed unconstitutional. The reform would also introduce a new "override clause," which would allow the Knesset to override a High Court decision striking down a law, provided that a majority of 61 Knesset members support the override.

## Override clause

The override clause would allow the Knesset to override a High Court decision striking down a law, provided that a majority of 61 Knesset members support the override. Proponents of the reform argue that this would ensure that the elected branches of government have the final say on matters of policy, while critics argue that it would undermine the ability of the judiciary to protect individual rights and the rule of law.

## Abolition of "unreasonableness" grounds

The proposed reforms would also abolish the "unreasonableness" grounds for judicial review, which allows the High Court of Justice to strike down government decisions that are deemed unreasonable. Proponents of the reform argue that this would reduce the ability of the judiciary to micromanage government decision-making, while critics argue that it would allow the government to make arbitrary and unreasonable decisions without accountability.

### Arguments in favor of the reform

Proponents of the reform argue that the abolition of the "unreasonableness" grounds would allow the government to make decisions without fear of judicial interference, and would reduce the number of frivolous petitions filed with the High Court of Justice.

### Arguments against the reform

Critics of the reform argue that the abolition of the "unreasonableness" grounds would allow the government to make arbitrary and unreasonable decisions without accountability, and would undermine the ability of the judiciary to protect individual rights and the rule of law.

## Status of the Attorney-General

The proposed reforms would also give the Attorney-General greater independence and autonomy, allowing him to make decisions without fear of government interference. However, critics argue that this would also reduce the ability of the Attorney-General to advise the government on the legality of its actions, and would create a conflict of interest between the Attorney-General's role as a government advisor and his role as an independent law enforcement officer.

# Reactions

## National

The proposed reforms have sparked intense debate within Israeli society, with supporters arguing that they are necessary to restore the balance of power between the judiciary and the elected branches of government, while critics argue that they would undermine the independence of the judiciary and the rule of law.

## International

The proposed reforms have also sparked international concern, with several countries and international organizations expressing concerns about the impact of the reforms on the independence of the judiciary and the rule of law in Israel.

## Connection to the Israeli–Palestinian conflict

Some critics of the reforms have argued that they are connected to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and that they would allow the government to pursue policies that are detrimental to the rights of Palestinians without fear of judicial review. However, proponents of the reforms argue that they are necessary to ensure the security and stability of the State of Israel, and that they would not have any impact on the rights of Palestinians.

# Suspension and overruling

In March 2023, the High Court of Justice issued a temporary injunction suspending the implementation of the reforms, pending a final decision on their constitutionality. The case is ongoing, and a decision is expected in 2024.

Technoblade was an American YouTube personality and Minecraft player known for his unique and entertaining content. He initially gained popularity on the platform in 2011 and went on to become one of the most well-known and respected figures in the Minecraft community.

# Internet career

Technoblade began his YouTube career in 2011, initially focusing on Minecraft gameplay and tutorials. Over time, he expanded his content to include other games, such as Roblox and Terraria. However, Minecraft remained his primary focus, and he became particularly known for his skill and creativity in the game.

Technoblade's early content was often characterized by his dry wit and sarcastic commentary, which resonated with his audience. He also became known for his participation in various Minecraft challenges and tournaments, where he would often team up with other popular YouTubers.

As his channel grew in popularity, Technoblade began to collaborate with other creators and develop more complex and elaborate content. He became a key figure in the Minecraft community, known for his expertise and innovative gameplay.

In addition to his YouTube channel, Technoblade was also active on social media platforms, such as Twitter and Instagram. He used these platforms to engage with his fans, share updates about his content, and provide insights into his personal life.

# Personal life

Technoblade was born on June 1, 1999, in the United States. Little is known about his early life or family, as he kept this aspect of his life private. However, he did share some details about his personal life with his fans, including his struggles with anxiety and depression.

Technoblade was open about his mental health, using his platform to raise awareness and reduce stigma around mental illness. He often incorporated themes of mental health into his content, using humor and storytelling to help his audience cope with their own struggles.

In his free time, Technoblade enjoyed playing video games, watching movies, and reading books. He was also a self-proclaimed "dog dad," often sharing photos and updates about his beloved pets on social media.

Despite his illness, Technoblade continued to create content and engage with his fans. He remained optimistic and determined, using his platform to raise awareness about cancer and support others who were going through similar experiences.

Sadly, Technoblade passed away on June 30, 2022, at the age of 23. His death was met with an outpouring of tributes and condolences from the Minecraft community and beyond.

## Reactions and tributes

Many popular YouTubers and streamers shared heartfelt messages and memories of Technoblade, praising his kindness, creativity, and generosity. Minecraft creator Markus "Notch" Persson also paid tribute to Technoblade, calling him "a true Minecraft legend."

In the days and weeks following his death, fans created countless tributes, including fan art, music, and in-game memorials. The Minecraft community came together to celebrate Technoblade's life and legacy, demonstrating the profound impact he had on so many people.

FIFA World Cup Records and Statistics

The FIFA World Cup, an international soccer tournament held every four years, has been the stage for numerous records and statistics since its inception in 1930. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the records and statistics of the FIFA World Cup, covering various aspects of the tournament, including team and player performances, goalscoring, goalkeeping, coaching, refereeing, and discipline.

# List of Tournaments

The FIFA World Cup has been held 22 times, with the first tournament taking place in 1930 in Uruguay and the most recent one in 2018 in Russia. The list of tournaments includes:

* 1930 FIFA World Cup in Uruguay
* 1934 FIFA World Cup in Italy
* 1938 FIFA World Cup in France
* 1950 FIFA World Cup in Brazil
* 1954 FIFA World Cup in Switzerland
* 1958 FIFA World Cup in Sweden
* 1962 FIFA World Cup in Chile
* 1966 FIFA World Cup in England
* 1970 FIFA World Cup in Mexico

* 1998 FIFA World Cup in France

* 2006 FIFA World Cup in Germany

* 2018 FIFA World Cup in Russia

# Overall Team Records

This section provides an overview of the overall team records in the FIFA World Cup, including the most titles won, most finishes in the top two, most second-place finishes, and most World Cup appearances.

## Most Titles

Brazil is the most successful team in the FIFA World Cup, having won the tournament five times (1958, 1962, 1970, 1994, and 2002). Germany and Italy are the second-most successful teams, each having won the tournament four times.

## Most Finishes in the Top Two

Germany has finished in the top two of the FIFA World Cup a record eight times (1934, 1954, 1958, 1966, 1974, 1982, 1986, and 2014). Brazil has finished in the top two seven times (1950, 1958, 1962, 1970, 1994, 1998, and 2002).

## Most Second-Place Finishes

Germany has finished in second place a record four times (1954, 1966, 1982, and 2002). Netherlands has finished in second place three times (1974, 1978, and 2010).

## Most World Cup Appearances

Brazil has appeared in the FIFA World Cup a record 22 times, having participated in every tournament since the inaugural edition in 1930. Germany has appeared in the tournament 20 times.

# Finals Records by Team

This section provides an overview of the finals records by team, including the most appearances, most wins, and most losses.

## Most Appearances

Germany has appeared in the most FIFA World Cup finals, with a total of eight appearances (1934, 1954, 1958, 1966, 1974, 1982, 1986, and 2014). Brazil has appeared in the finals seven times (1950, 1958, 1962, 1970, 1994, 1998, and 2002).

## Most Wins

Brazil has won the most FIFA World Cup finals, with a total of five wins (1958, 1962, 1970, 1994, and 2002). Germany and Italy have each won the finals four times.

## Most Losses

Germany has lost the most FIFA World Cup finals, with a total of four losses (1954, 1966, 1982, and 2002). Netherlands has lost the finals three times (1974, 1978, and 2010).

# Teams Statistics

This section provides an overview of the teams statistics in the FIFA World Cup, including the most titles, most finishes in the top two, most second-place finishes, and most World Cup appearances.

article:
Jackass Forever
================

Jackass Forever is a 2022 American action comedy film directed by Jeff Tremaine and written by Tremaine, Johnny Knoxville, and Spike Jonze. The film is the fourth main installment in the Jackass film series and stars the regular cast of Johnny Knoxville, Steve-O, Dave England, Wee Man, and Danger Ehren, alongside newcomers Rachel Wolfson, Sean "Poopies" McInerney, and Zach Holmes.

Synopsis
--------

Jackass Forever follows the same format as its predecessors, featuring a series of absurd and often painful stunts, pranks, and skits performed by the cast. The film features a mix of old and new cast members, with the newcomers bringing a fresh dynamic to the series. The movie does not have a traditional narrative structure, instead opting for a series of loosely connected sketches and stunts.

Cast
-----

The main cast of Jackass Forever includes:

* Johnny Knoxville as himself
* Steve-O as himself
* Dave England as himself
* Wee Man as himself
* Danger Ehren as himself
* Rachel Wolfson as herself
* Sean "Poopies" McInerney as himself
* Zach Holmes as himself

### Guest appearances

The film features several guest appearances, including:

* Tony Hawk as himself
* Shaquille O'Neal as himself
* Rob Dyrdek as himself
* Eric André as himself
* Machine Gun Kelly as himself

### Crew

The crew of Jackass Forever includes:

* Jeff Tremaine as director
* Johnny Knoxville as writer and producer
* Spike Jonze as writer and producer
* Steve-O as executive producer
* Dave England as executive producer
* Wee Man as executive producer
* Danger Ehren as executive producer

Production
----------

### Development

Development on Jackass Forever began in 2019, with the cast and crew reuniting for the first time in over a decade. The film was originally set to be released in 2021, but production was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

### Bam Margera's firing

In May 2021, it was announced that Bam Margera had been fired from the film due to his struggles with addiction and mental health. Margera had been a main cast member in the previous Jackass films, and his departure was met with concern from fans and fellow cast members.

### Casting

The casting process for Jackass Forever involved a mix of old and new cast members. Rachel Wolfson, Sean "Poopies" McInerney, and Zach Holmes were all newcomers to the series, while the rest of the cast consisted of veterans from the previous films.

### Filming

Filming on Jackass Forever took place over several months in 2020 and 2021. The cast and crew traveled to various locations around the world, including the United States, Australia, and Europe.

### Injuries

As with previous Jackass films, the cast suffered several injuries during filming. Steve-O and Dave England were both hospitalized at different points during production, while Johnny Knoxville suffered a concussion and several broken bones.

Release
-------

Jackass Forever was released in theaters on February 4, 2022. The film was distributed by Paramount Pictures and received a wide release in the United States.

### Home media

Jackass Forever was released on digital platforms on March 22, 2022, and on Blu-ray and DVD on April 19, 2022.

Reception
----------

### Box office

Jackass Forever grossed over $57 million at the domestic box office and over $23 million internationally, for a worldwide total of over $80 million.

### Critical response

The film received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising the cast's chemistry and the film's humor. The film holds a 86% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 142 reviews, with an average rating of 6.8/10.

Jackass 4.5
------------

In May 2022, it was announced that a spin-off film titled Jackass 4.5 would be released on Netflix. The film features a mix of new and unused footage from the production of Jackass Forever, as well as some new material.

article:
Assassination of John F. Kennedy

The assassination of John F. Kennedy, the 35th President of the United States, occurred on November 22, 1963, in Dallas, Texas. Kennedy was shot while riding in an open-top car in a motorcade through Dealey Plaza, a public park in downtown Dallas. The event shocked the nation and led to a wave of grief, speculation, and investigation that continues to this day.

# Background

## Kennedy

John F. Kennedy was born on May 29, 1917, in Brookline, Massachusetts. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II and later became a congressman and senator from Massachusetts. In 1960, he was elected President, defeating Republican candidate Richard Nixon in a close election. Kennedy's presidency was marked by significant events, including the Cuban Missile Crisis, the Bay of Pigs invasion, and the early stages of the Vietnam War.

## Oswald

Lee Harvey Oswald was born on October 18, 1939, in New Orleans, Louisiana. He grew up in a troubled home and dropped out of high school. Oswald served in the U.S. Marine Corps and later defected to the Soviet Union, where he lived for several years. He returned to the United States in 1962 and began working at the Texas School Book Depository in Dallas.

# November 22

## Kennedy's arrival in Dallas and route to Dealey Plaza

On November 22, 1963, President Kennedy arrived at Love Field in Dallas, Texas, on a campaign trip to boost his re-election chances. He was accompanied by First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy, Texas Governor John Connally, and Senator Ralph Yarborough. After a brief speech at the airport, the presidential motorcade began its journey through downtown Dallas, with the President and First Lady riding in an open-top 1961 Lincoln Continental limousine.

## Shooting

At around 12:30 pm, the motorcade entered Dealey Plaza, a public park in downtown Dallas. As the limousine turned onto Elm Street, shots rang out from the sixth floor of the Texas School Book Depository building. One bullet struck Kennedy in the neck, and another bullet hit him in the head. The President slumped forward, and the limousine sped away to Parkland Memorial Hospital.

## Aftermath in Dealey Plaza

Panic broke out in Dealey Plaza as people realized what had happened. Witnesses pointed to the Texas School Book Depository building, and police officers rushed to the scene. Lee Harvey Oswald, who had been watching the motorcade from the sixth floor, fled the building and left his rifle behind.

## Oswald's flight, killing of J. D. Tippit, and arrest

Oswald walked to the nearby Greyhound bus station and boarded a bus, but he got off a few blocks away. He then walked to the Texas Theatre, a movie theater in the Oak Cliff neighborhood of Dallas. At around 1:45 pm, Oswald shot and killed Dallas police officer J. D. Tippit, who had stopped him for questioning. After a brief struggle, Oswald was arrested by police

2022 UK Championship

The 2022 UK Championship was a professional snooker tournament that took place from 12 to 20 November 2022 at the Barbican Centre in York, England. The tournament was the third ranking event of the 2022-23 snooker season and the 46th edition of the UK Championship.

Format

The 2022 UK Championship was a 128-player tournament, with players competing in a knockout format. The tournament was divided into several rounds, with the winner of each match advancing to the next round.

## Prize fund

The total prize fund for the 2022 UK Championship was £850,000, with the winner receiving £170,000.

Summary

The 2022 UK Championship was won by Mark Allen, who defeated Ding Junhui 10-7 in the final. This was Allen's first UK Championship title and his third career ranking title.

## Qualifying rounds

The qualifying rounds for the 2022 UK Championship took place from 5 to 9 November 2022 at the Ponds Forge International Sports Centre in Sheffield, England. The top 128 players in the world rankings entered the tournament, with the top 16 players seeded and the remaining players competing in the qualifying rounds.

## First round

The first round of the 2022 UK Championship took place from 12 to 15 November 2022. The matches were played as best-of-11 frames, with the winner advancing to the next round.

## Second round

The second round of the 2022 UK Championship took place on 15 and 16 November 2022. The matches were played as best-of-11 frames, with the winner advancing to the next round.

## Quarter-finals

The quarter-finals of the 2022 UK Championship took place on 17 and 18 November 2022. The matches were played as best-of-11 frames, with the winner advancing to the semi-finals.

## Semi-finals

The semi-finals of the 2022 UK Championship took place on 19 November 2022. The matches were played as best-of-11 frames, with the winner advancing to the final.

## Final

The final of the 2022 UK Championship took place on 20 November 2022. The match was played as best-of-19 frames, with Mark Allen winning 10-7 against Ding Junhui.

## Final

The final of the 2022 UK Championship was played between Mark Allen and Ding Junhui. Allen won the match 10-7, winning his first UK Championship title.

article:
Greece's Next Top Model Season 5

Greece's Next Top Model Season 5 is the fifth season of the Greek reality television series Greece's Next Top Model, which premiered on September 13, 2018, on Skai TV. The show is based on the American television series America's Next Top Model and features a group of young women competing against each other to win the title of Greece's Next Top Model.

# Cast

## Contestants

The fifth season of Greece's Next Top Model features 20 contestants from all over Greece. The contestants were chosen from a pool of thousands of applicants who auditioned for the show. The contestants range in age from 18 to 25 and come from different backgrounds and professions.

## Judges

The judges for the fifth season of Greece's Next Top Model include:

* Vicky Kaya: A Greek model and television presenter who has been hosting the show since its inception.
* Dimitris Skoulos: A Greek fashion designer and stylist who has been working in the industry for over 20 years.
* Angelos Bratis: A Greek fashion photographer who has worked with top models and celebrities.

## Other cast members

Other cast members include:

* Elena Christopoulou: A Greek model and television presenter who serves as a mentor to the contestants.
* Giorgos Konstantinou: A Greek fashion designer who provides guidance and support to the contestants.

# Episode summaries

## Episodes 1–5: Auditions

The first five episodes of the season feature the auditions, where thousands of young women from all over Greece compete for a spot in the top 20. The contestants are put through various challenges and interviews, and the judges select the top 20 contestants who will move on to the next round.

## Episodes 5–6: Bootcamp

In episodes 5 and 6, the top 20 contestants participate in a boot camp, where they are put through a series of physical and mental challenges to test their endurance and determination.

## Episode 7: Wuthering Heights

In episode 7, the contestants participate in a photo shoot inspired by the classic novel Wuthering Heights. The contestants are dressed in period costumes and are asked to pose in a dramatic and romantic setting.

## Episode 8: Drive-Thru Diner

In episode 8, the contestants participate in a commercial shoot for a drive-thru diner. The contestants are asked to pose in a fun and playful setting, and the judges evaluate their ability to work in a fast-paced environment.

## Episode 9: Tennis

In episode 9, the contestants participate in a photo shoot inspired by the sport of tennis. The contestants are dressed in tennis attire and are asked to pose in a dynamic and athletic setting.

## Episode 10: Four Seasons Catwalk

In episode 10, the contestants participate in a catwalk challenge, where they are asked to model clothing from four different seasons. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to walk the catwalk and showcase the clothing in a confident and stylish manner.

## Episode 11: Get The Job Done

In episode 11, the contestants participate in a challenge where they are asked to complete a series of tasks in a limited amount of time. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to work under pressure and complete the tasks efficiently.

## Episode 12: Fashion In The City

In episode 12, the contestants participate in a photo shoot inspired by the city of Athens. The contestants are dressed in urban attire and are asked to pose in a modern and trendy setting.

## Episode 13: The Makeover

In episode 13, the contestants undergo a makeover, where they are given a new hairstyle and makeup look. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to adapt to the new look and showcase their confidence and style.

## Episode 14: Bikini Debate

In episode 14, the contestants participate in a debate about the ethics of modeling in bikinis. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to express their opinions and engage in a respectful and intelligent discussion.

## Episode 15: Back To The Future

In episode 15, the contestants participate in a photo shoot inspired by the classic movie Back to the Future. The contestants are dressed in futuristic attire and are asked to pose in a fun and playful setting.

## Episode 16: Alive & Kicking

In episode 16, the contestants participate in a challenge where they are asked to create a short video showcasing their personality and style. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to express themselves creatively and showcase their confidence and charisma.

In episode 18, the contestants participate in a challenge where they are asked to model clothing on a sailboat. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to work in a challenging environment and showcase their confidence and style.

In episode 19, the contestants participate in a photo shoot inspired by the theme of light. The contestants are dressed in shimmering attire and are asked to pose in a dynamic and energetic setting.

## Episode 20: Dirty Ride

In episode 20, the contestants participate in a challenge where they are asked to model clothing on a motorcycle. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to work in a fast-paced environment and showcase their confidence and style.

## Episode 21: Glam Wars

In episode 21, the contestants participate in a challenge where they are asked to create a short video showcasing their glamor and style. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to express themselves creatively and showcase their confidence and charisma.

In episode 22, the contestants participate in a challenge where they are asked to create clothing from recycled materials. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to think creatively and showcase their eco-friendly style.

In episode 23, the contestants participate in a photo shoot inspired by the theme of summer. The contestants are dressed in summer attire and are asked to pose in a fun and playful setting.

In episode 24, the contestants participate in a challenge where they are asked to model clothing at a party. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to work in a social environment and showcase their confidence and style.

In episode 25, the contestants participate in a photo shoot inspired by the theme of transparency. The contestants are dressed in transparent attire and are asked to pose in a sensual and alluring setting.

In episode 26, the contestants participate in a challenge where they are asked to model clothing with a pet. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to work with animals and showcase their confidence and style.

In episode 27, the contestants participate in a challenge where they are asked to model clothing in a car. The contestants are evaluated on their ability to work in a confined environment and showcase their confidence and style.

Each week, the judges select the bottom two contestants who are at risk of elimination. The contestants are evaluated on their performance in the challenges and photo shoots, and the judges decide which contestant will be eliminated.

The contestants are ranked in order of their performance, and the contestant with the highest average call-out order is considered the strongest competitor.

article:
# 2022 United States House of Representatives elections in California

The 2022 United States House of Representatives elections in California were held on November 8, 2022, to elect the 52 U.S. Representatives from the state of California, one from each of the state's 52 congressional districts. The elections coincided with the 2022 United States Senate elections and the 2022 California gubernatorial election.

# Overview

## Statewide

The 2022 elections in California saw a significant shift in the state's congressional delegation. The state lost one seat due to reapportionment following the 2020 United States Census. As a result, several incumbent members of Congress faced off against each other in new districts.

## District

California's 52 congressional districts were redrawn following the 2020 census. The new district boundaries took effect for the 2022 elections. Several districts saw significant changes, with some incumbents facing new challenges in their re-election bids.

# District 1

## Candidates

* Max Steiner (Democratic)

* Michael Shoen (Democratic)

* Max Steiner: California Democratic Party

2023 World Baseball Classic

The 2023 World Baseball Classic was the fifth edition of the World Baseball Classic, an international baseball tournament organized by the World Baseball Softball Confederation (WBSC) and sanctioned by the Fédération Internationale de Baseball (FIBA). The tournament featured 20 national teams competing in a round-robin format, with the top two teams from each pool advancing to the knockout stage. The 2023 World Baseball Classic took place from March 8 to March 21, 2023, with games played across four venues in Taiwan, Japan, the United States, and Miami.

# Teams

## Qualification

The 2023 World Baseball Classic featured 20 national teams, with 16 teams qualifying from the previous edition and four new teams earning spots through a qualifying tournament. The qualifying tournament took place in 2022, with 16 teams competing in four pools of four teams each. The top two teams from each pool advanced to the 2023 World Baseball Classic.

## Draw

The draw for the 2023 World Baseball Classic took place on July 7, 2022, in Miami, Florida. The 20 teams were divided into four pools of five teams each, with the teams seeded based on their performance in the previous edition.

# Venues

The 2023 World Baseball Classic was played across four venues:

* Taichung Intercontinental Baseball Stadium in Taichung, Taiwan
* Tokyo Dome in Tokyo, Japan
* LoanDepot Park in Miami, Florida, United States
* Chase Field in Phoenix, Arizona, United States

## Attendance

The 2023 World Baseball Classic saw a total attendance of 1,010,000 fans across the four venues. The highest-attended game was the final between Japan and the United States, which drew a crowd of 36,000 fans at LoanDepot Park.

## Team base camps

Each team had a designated base camp, where they stayed and trained during the tournament. The base camps were located in the following cities:

* Taichung, Taiwan: Chinese Taipei, Netherlands, Italy, Cuba
* Tokyo, Japan: Japan, South Korea, Australia, China
* Miami, Florida, United States: United States, Dominican Republic, Venezuela, Puerto Rico
* Phoenix, Arizona, United States: Mexico, Canada, Colombia, Great Britain

# Rosters

Each team had a roster of 28 players, with a minimum of 13 pitchers and 10 position players. The teams were allowed to make roster changes during the tournament, with a maximum of two changes per team.

# Officiating

## Umpires

The 2023 World Baseball Classic featured a team of 24 umpires from around the world. The umpires were selected by the WBSC and underwent a rigorous training program before the tournament.

## Supervisors

The WBSC appointed a team of supervisors to oversee the umpires during the tournament. The supervisors were experienced umpires who had worked in previous international tournaments.

# Prize money

The total prize money for the 2023 World Baseball Classic was $14.5 million, with the winning team receiving $2.5 million.

# Group stage

The group stage of the 2023 World Baseball Classic featured 20 teams competing in four pools of five teams each. The top two teams from each pool advanced to the knockout stage.

## Pool A

Pool A featured Chinese Taipei, Netherlands, Italy, Cuba, and Panama. Chinese Taipei and Cuba advanced to the knockout stage.

## Pool B

Pool B featured Japan, South Korea, Australia, China, and Czech Republic. Japan and South Korea advanced to the knockout stage.

## Pool C

Pool C featured United States, Dominican Republic, Venezuela, Puerto Rico, and Israel. United States and Venezuela advanced to the knockout stage.

## Pool D

Pool D featured Mexico, Canada, Colombia, Great Britain, and Nicaragua. Mexico and Canada advanced to the knockout stage.

# Knockout stage

The knockout stage of the 2023 World Baseball Classic featured the top two teams from each pool competing in a single-elimination bracket.

## Bracket

The bracket for the knockout stage was as follows:

* Quarterfinals: A1 vs. B2, A2 vs. B1, C1 vs. D2, C2 vs. D1
* Semifinals: Winner of A1/B2 vs. Winner of C1/D2, Winner of A2/B1 vs. Winner of C2/D1
* Final: Winner of Semifinal 1 vs. Winner of Semifinal 2

article:
John Green
================

John Michael Green is an American author, YouTube personality, and educational content creator. He is best known for his young adult novels, particularly _The Fault in Our Stars_, which has sold millions of copies worldwide and was adapted into a successful film. Green's online presence, including his YouTube channel and educational projects, has also garnered a significant following.

Early life and education
------------------------

John Green was born on August 24, 1977, in Indianapolis, Indiana. He grew up in Florida and Alabama, and developed an interest in writing at an early age. Green attended Kenyon College in Gambier, Ohio, where he studied English and graduated in 2000. After college, he worked as a chaplain at a children's hospital in Ohio, which later influenced his writing.

Career
-------

### Early career and novels (2001–2006)

#### Booklist magazine and Looking for Alaska

Green began his career as a book reviewer for _Booklist_ magazine, where he worked from 2000 to 2005. During this time, he wrote his first novel, _Looking for Alaska_, which was published in 2005. The book received positive reviews and won the Michael L. Printz Award in 2006.

#### An Abundance of Katherines

In 2006, Green published his second novel, _An Abundance of Katherines_, which received critical acclaim and won the Michael L. Printz Award in 2007.

### Online and literary collaborations (2007–2011)

#### Paper Towns and collaborative works

In 2008, Green published his third novel, _Paper Towns_, which was a _New York Times_ bestseller. He also began collaborating with other authors, including Maureen Johnson and Lauren Myracle, on the _Let It Snow_ anthology.

#### Online video beginnings

In 2007, Green began creating online video content, including the _Brotherhood 2.0_ project, where he and his brother, Hank, exchanged video blogs for a year. This project helped establish Green's online presence and led to the creation of his YouTube channel.

### Breakout success (2012–2016)

#### The Fault in Our Stars and adaptations

In 2012, Green published his fourth novel, _The Fault in Our Stars_, which became a huge success and debuted at number one on the _New York Times_ bestseller list. The book was adapted into a film in 2014, which grossed over $304 million worldwide.

#### Focus on educational content

Green's online presence expanded during this period, with the launch of his educational YouTube channel, Crash Course, in 2011. The channel offers courses on a range of subjects, including literature, history, and science.

#### Appearances

Green has appeared at numerous book festivals, conferences, and events, including the _National Book Festival_ and the _Teen Choice Awards_.

### Established author and internet personality (2017–2022)

#### Turtles All the Way Down

In 2017, Green published his fifth novel, _Turtles All the Way Down_, which debuted at number one on the _New York Times_ bestseller list.

#### The Anthropocene Reviewed

In 2020, Green published his first non-fiction book, _The Anthropocene Reviewed_, which explores the human impact on the environment.

#### Further adaptations

Several of Green's novels are currently in development for film and television adaptations, including _Looking for Alaska_ and _An Abundance of Katherines_.

#### Partners In Health

Green has been involved with the non-profit organization _Partners In Health_ since 2012, which works to provide healthcare to underserved communities around the world.

#### Complexly and DFTBA

Green co-founded the production company _Complexly_ in 2012, which produces educational content for YouTube and other platforms. He also founded the online store _DFTBA Records_ in 2008, which sells merchandise and music.

#### Appearances and other projects

Green has appeared on various TV shows, including _The Colbert Report_ and _Conan_. He has also created several podcasts, including _Dear Hank and John_ and _The Anthropocene Reviewed_.

### Focus on global health (2022–present)

#### Anti-tuberculosis advocacy

Green has become increasingly involved in global health advocacy, particularly in the fight against tuberculosis. He has worked with organizations such as the _World Health Organization_ and _Partners In Health_ to raise awareness and support for TB research and treatment.

#### Other efforts

Green has also been involved in various other charitable efforts, including supporting education and literacy programs around the world.

Influence and reception
------------------------

### Books

Green's novels have been widely praised for their thoughtful and nuanced exploration of complex themes, including mental health, relationships, and identity.

#### Book banning

Several of Green's novels have been challenged or banned in schools and libraries due to their mature themes and content.

### Online ventures

Green's online presence has been praised for its creativity and educational value. His YouTube channels, including Crash Course and Vlogbrothers, have been viewed millions of times and have helped to establish him as a leading voice in online education.

Personal life and interests
---------------------------

Green is married to Sarah Urist Green, an artist and curator. They have two children together and live in Indianapolis, Indiana. Green is an avid reader and has a strong interest in history, science, and philosophy.

article:
Mahsa Amini Protests

The Mahsa Amini protests were a series of anti-government protests that took place in Iran, starting on September 16, 2022, following the death of Mahsa Amini, a 22-year-old Iranian Kurdish woman, in police custody. The protests, which were sparked by Amini's death, quickly evolved into a broader movement against the Islamic Republic's government and its policies, particularly those related to women's rights and freedoms.

# Background

## Condition of women and the Islamic Republic

The Islamic Republic of Iran has been criticized for its treatment of women, who face strict laws and regulations governing their behavior, dress, and movement. Women in Iran are required to wear the hijab, a headscarf, in public, and are subject to strict dress codes. They are also barred from certain professions and are restricted in their ability to travel and obtain education.

## Protest movements under the Islamic Republic

The Islamic Republic has faced numerous protest movements since its establishment in 1979, with many of these movements focusing on issues related to democracy, human rights, and women's rights. The most notable of these protests was the 2009 Green Movement, which was sparked by allegations of electoral fraud and saw widespread demonstrations against the government.

## Mahsa Amini's arrest and death in custody

On September 13, 2022, Mahsa Amini was arrested by Iran's morality police in Tehran for allegedly violating the country's dress code. Amini was taken to a police station, where she was beaten and suffered a heart attack. She was taken to a hospital, where she died on September 16, 2022. The government claimed that Amini had died from a pre-existing medical condition, but her family and eyewitnesses disputed this, saying that she had been beaten by police.

# Protests

## Slogans and grievances

The protests that followed Amini's death were marked by slogans and chants calling for an end to the Islamic Republic and its policies. Protesters also called for the resignation of President Ebrahim Raisi and the release of all political prisoners. The protests were fueled by widespread anger and frustration with the government's treatment of women, as well as its handling of the economy, education, and healthcare.

## Iranian public opinion

The protests were widely supported by the Iranian public, with many people taking to social media to express their outrage and solidarity with the protesters. According to a survey conducted by the Iranian Students' Polling Agency, 80% of Iranians believed that the government was responsible for Amini's death, and 75% believed that the protests were justified.

## Protest techniques

Protesters used a variety of techniques to evade the police and security forces, including the use of social media to coordinate their movements and the use of proxy servers to avoid internet shutdowns. They also used traditional protest tactics, such as chanting slogans, waving flags, and blocking streets.

## Civil boycotts

Many Iranians participated in civil boycotts, refusing to buy goods or services from companies that were seen as supporting the government. They also called for international companies to boycott Iran and for governments to impose sanctions on the country.

## Media Western coverage

The protests received widespread coverage in Western media, with many outlets focusing on the bravery and resilience of the protesters. The coverage was seen as largely sympathetic to the protesters, with many outlets condemning the government's response to the protests.

# Casualties, government response

## Casualties

According to human rights groups, at least 500 people were killed in the protests, including protesters, security forces, and bystanders. Many more were injured, and thousands were arrested.

### Government casualties
